primordials.name: The Ancestor
primordials.description: The honored dead who remain connected to the living. Keeper of lineage, tradition, and the wisdom of those who came before. Bridge between living and dead.

primordials.name: The Creator
primordials.description: The generative force that brings form from formlessness. Pure creative potential manifesting into actuality.

primordials.name: The Crone
primordials.description: Wisdom beyond childbearing. The power of ending, transition, and the gate to death. Keeper of mysteries that only age reveals.

primordials.name: The Destroyer
primordials.description: The force of necessary ending, clearing, and dissolution. Makes space for new creation through sacred destruction.

primordials.name: The Divine Child
primordials.description: The symbol of new beginning, potential, and wholeness. Vulnerability combined with cosmic significance. The future breaking into the present.

primordials.name: The Great Father
primordials.description: The principle of authority, law, protection, and structure. Contains both the wise father who guides and the tyrannical father who oppresses.

primordials.name: The Great Mother
primordials.description: The source of life, nourishment, protection, and unconditional love. Contains both the nurturing mother who gives life and the terrible mother who devours.

primordials.name: The Healer
primordials.description: The one who restores wholeness. Works with wounds - physical, emotional, spiritual - to bring integration. Often carries the wound they heal.

primordials.name: The Hero
primordials.description: The one who answers the call, faces trials, and returns transformed. The ego's journey toward wholeness through courageous action.

primordials.name: The Lover
primordials.description: The force of connection, passion, desire, and union. Seeks merging and relationship with the Other. Encompasses erotic, romantic, aesthetic, and mystical love.

primordials.name: The Magician
primordials.description: The transformer who works with hidden laws to create change. Master of the liminal, worker of will. Understands the secret connections between things.

primordials.name: The Maiden
primordials.description: Pure potential of the feminine before commitment. Independence, self-containment, and the power of being unto oneself.

primordials.name: The Monster
primordials.description: The inhuman Other that embodies what lies beyond civilization. Raw instinct, chaos, the untamed. Both terrifying and potentially sacred.

primordials.name: The Outcast
primordials.description: The one who is rejected, exiled, or set apart from community. Carries the projection of collective shadow but also holds unique perspective and potential for return with gifts.

primordials.name: The Preserver
primordials.description: The force of maintenance, protection, and continuation. Holds the world in balance between creation and destruction.

primordials.name: The Psychopomp
primordials.description: Guide of souls between worlds. Escorts the dying, leads the living through transitions. Specialist of thresholds and passages.

primordials.name: The Rebel
primordials.description: The one who stands against corrupt order. Fights for freedom and transformation of unjust systems through direct opposition.

primordials.name: The Self
primordials.description: The totality of psyche. The organizing principle that unifies all opposites. The goal of individuation. The Self is the center and circumference, containing all other archetypes in balance.

primordials.name: The Shadow
primordials.description: The rejected, denied, and repressed aspects of self and collective. That which we refuse to see becomes the Shadow. Unlike other primordials, Shadow is both an archetype AND a universal modifier that can apply to any archetype.

primordials.name: The Sovereign
primordials.description: The principle of rightful authority, responsibility, and order. Rules through legitimacy, not force. Includes King and Queen.

primordials.name: The Trickster
primordials.description: The boundary-crosser who disrupts order to reveal hidden truths. Agent of necessary chaos and transformation through mischief, cunning, and sacred foolishness.

primordials.name: The Twin
primordials.description: The doubled self, the other who is same. Embodies duality, mirroring, and the paradox of identity. Often one light and one dark, or mortal and immortal.

primordials.name: The Warrior
primordials.description: The force of directed aggression, discipline, and protection. Fights for what matters with skill and courage.

primordials.name: The Wise Elder
primordials.description: The holder of wisdom accumulated through experience. Guide, teacher, and keeper of knowledge. Includes both Wise Old Man and Wise Old Woman / Crone.

archetypes.name: Albedo (Whitening)
archetypes.description: The second stage. Purification and washing. The emergence of lunar consciousness, anima/animus work.

archetypes.name: Calcination
archetypes.description: Burning to white powder. Destruction of ego attachments and false identifications.

archetypes.name: Citrinitas (Yellowing)
archetypes.description: The third stage. Solar dawn, intellectual illumination. Often merged with Rubedo in later alchemy.

archetypes.name: Coagulation
archetypes.description: Final crystallization. The Stone is formed. Embodiment of the transformed self.

archetypes.name: Conjunction
archetypes.description: The Sacred Marriage of opposites. Union of purified elements, integration.

archetypes.name: Dissolution
archetypes.description: Dissolving calcined matter in water. Letting go, emotional processing, surrender.

archetypes.name: Distillation
archetypes.description: Repeated distillation to purify. Extracting the essential, releasing the impure.

archetypes.name: Fermentation
archetypes.description: New life arising from death. Spiritual inspiration, quickening of the soul.

archetypes.name: Mercurius (Philosophical Mercury)
archetypes.description: Philosophical Mercury. The volatile, transformative spirit. Both poison and cure.

archetypes.name: Nigredo (Blackening)
archetypes.description: The first stage of the Work. Breakdown, decay, confrontation with shadow. The death that precedes rebirth.

archetypes.name: Philosopher's Stone
archetypes.description: The goal of the Great Work. Transmutes lead to gold, confers immortality.

archetypes.name: Prima Materia
archetypes.description: The First Matter. The raw, undifferentiated starting material of the Work.

archetypes.name: Rubedo (Reddening)
archetypes.description: The final stage. The red of sunrise and sunset. Achievement of the Philosopher's Stone, integration of opposites.

archetypes.name: Separation
archetypes.description: Separating the pure from the impure. Discernment, analysis, seeing clearly.

archetypes.name: Sulphur (Philosophical Sulphur)
archetypes.description: Philosophical Sulphur. The fiery, active principle. Soul, desire, combustibility.

archetypes.name: Aganju
archetypes.description: The Orisha of volcanoes, wilderness, and the untamed earth. Father of Shango in some lineages, he represents raw masculine earth power, the ferryman who carries people across rivers, and the volcanic force beneath the surface. He is invoked for strength to overcome impossible obstacles and cross dangerous thresholds.

archetypes.name: Anansi
archetypes.description: The Akan trickster spider-god who owns all stories. Anansi won the world’s stories from Nyame (the sky god) by capturing the most dangerous creatures. Represents wit triumphing over strength, the power of storytelling, and subversive intelligence. Survived the Middle Passage to become central to Caribbean and African-American folklore.

archetypes.name: Babalú-Ayé
archetypes.description: The feared and deeply respected Orisha of disease and healing, particularly epidemic illness. Covered in sores or hidden beneath raffia, he walks with a crutch. He both brings disease and has the power to cure it. Patron of the sick, disabled, and outcast, he teaches that suffering can lead to wisdom. His name was traditionally spoken only in whispers.

archetypes.name: Eshu
archetypes.description: The divine messenger and trickster who guards all crossroads, doorways, and thresholds. Nothing reaches the Orishas without passing through Eshu first - he must be propitiated before any ritual. He is neither good nor evil but embodies the dynamic chaos necessary for change. Master of languages who carries prayers to heaven and returns divine messages.

archetypes.name: Nana Buruku
archetypes.description: One of the most ancient Orishas, predating even Olodumare, she is the primordial mother associated with swamps, mud, and the boundary between life and death. She provided the clay from which Obatala formed humans. Her relationship with Ogun is hostile - she forbids iron in her worship because he used it to slay one of her children.

archetypes.name: Obatala
archetypes.description: The eldest Orisha and father of humanity, tasked by Olodumare with creating human bodies from clay. When he became drunk on palm wine and created deformed humans, he became their special protector. He embodies wisdom, patience, ethical purity, and cool (calm) energy. All things white are sacred to him.

relationships.target: Patient king who accepts wrongful imprisonment without complaint

archetypes.name: Obba
archetypes.description: The Orisha of marriage and domesticity, once Shango's senior wife. Tricked by the jealous Oshun into cutting off her own ear and putting it in Shango's soup to win his love, she was rejected and exiled. She rules the still waters of lakes and embodies the tragedy of misplaced devotion and the suffering of betrayed wives.

archetypes.name: Oduduwa
archetypes.description: The Orisha who completed the creation of earth when Obatala fell asleep drunk. He descended with soil in a snail shell, a five-toed hen to spread it, and a palm nut to plant. He founded Ile-Ife, the sacred city of the Yoruba, and is ancestor to all Yoruba kings. He represents the earthly complement to Obatala's heavenly nature.

archetypes.name: Ogun
archetypes.description: The fierce Orisha of iron, war, and labor who clears paths through the wilderness with his machete. First to descend to earth, he forged the tools that enabled civilization. Patron of blacksmiths, warriors, surgeons, and all who work with metal or cut through obstacles. His energy is hot, direct, and transformative through decisive action.

archetypes.name: Olodumare
archetypes.description: The Supreme Being and source of all ashé (divine energy/power). Olodumare is the transcendent creator who brought the universe into existence and delegated specific powers to the Orishas. Unlike the Orishas, Olodumare does not possess devotees or receive direct sacrifice, being beyond human petition yet the ultimate source of all blessing.

archetypes.name: Olokun
archetypes.description: The mysterious Orisha of the ocean depths, where sunlight cannot reach. Sometimes male, sometimes female, sometimes both or neither, Olokun embodies the unfathomable deep and all its treasures and terrors. In the diaspora, Olokun holds special significance as keeper of the ancestors lost in the Middle Passage, the millions who died in the crossing.

archetypes.name: Orunmila
archetypes.description: The Orisha of wisdom and divination, present when Olodumare created the universe - the only witness to all destinies. He does not possess devotees but speaks through the Ifá divination system, the most complex oracle in the world. Through his priests (babalawos), he reveals destiny and prescribes remedies. He knows all that was, is, and will be.

archetypes.name: Osanyin
archetypes.description: The one-eyed, one-armed, one-legged Orisha of herbs and plant medicine who lives in the forest and knows every plant's secret. All magical and healing work requires his herbs. He guards the secrets of herbal medicine and forest magic, communicating with the spirits within plants. His deformity comes from various mythical accidents but marks him as liminal.

archetypes.name: Oshun
archetypes.description: The beloved Orisha of fresh water, rivers, love, beauty, and prosperity. She embodies feminine grace, sensuality, and the sweet waters that sustain life. A powerful diplomat who once saved the Orishas when other powers failed, she is also a fierce protector who transforms into a warrior when her children are threatened. Patron of pregnancy and women's mysteries.

archetypes.name: Oya
archetypes.description: The fierce warrior Orisha of wind, storms, and transformation who guards the gates of the cemetery. Wife of Shango, she stole his secrets of thunder and fights alongside him in battle. She embodies radical change, death as transformation, and feminine warrior power. She can manifest as tornado, hurricane, or the breath of the dying.

archetypes.name: Shango
archetypes.description: The fiery Orisha of thunder and lightning, once the fourth king (Alafin) of the Oyo Empire. After accidentally killing his family with lightning, he hanged himself but transformed into an Orisha. He embodies masculine power, justice, strategic warfare, passion, and the destructive-creative force of the storm. Master of the bata drums and ecstatic dance.

archetypes.name: Yemoja
archetypes.description: The great mother Orisha of the ocean and salt water, source of all waters and mother of many Orishas. She embodies maternal love, fertility, protection of children, and the vast depths of the unconscious. In the diaspora, she became associated with the Middle Passage and the protection of those crossing waters. Her domain is the surface and upper layers of the ocean.

archetypes.name: Baiame
archetypes.description: The Sky Father and creator deity of many Southeastern Australian traditions, associated with the sky, creation of all things, and the establishment of sacred law. He created the world, instituted initiation ceremonies, and established the moral law. Often depicted with stars for eyes, he now dwells in the sky world (Bullima) but continues to watch over his creation.

archetypes.name: Bunyip
archetypes.description: The fearsome creature dwelling in waterholes, swamps, and rivers across Australia. Descriptions vary but generally include features of multiple animals. The Bunyip represents the dangers of water - keeping people from dangerous swimming holes, explaining drownings, and maintaining respect for waterways. It may have roots in megafauna memory or spiritual beings.

archetypes.name: Mimi Spirits
archetypes.description: The thin, elongated spirits who live in rock crevices in Arnhem Land, so thin they can only come out when there's no wind lest they be blown away. They taught humans to hunt, paint, and conduct ceremonies. They are both helpful and dangerous - they can heal but also cause illness if offended. Their distinctive figures appear in ancient rock art.

archetypes.name: Rainbow Serpent
archetypes.description: The great serpent who appears across Aboriginal Australia under many names, associated with water, rainbows, fertility, and the shaping of waterways and landscapes. The Rainbow Serpent carved rivers as it traveled, created waterholes where it rested, and is both life-giver (through water and fertility) and punisher of those who break sacred law. It continues to dwell in deep waters.

archetypes.name: Seven Sisters
archetypes.description: The ancestral women who fled across the land pursued by a lustful man (often associated with Orion), their journey creating many landmarks and sacred sites. Eventually they escaped into the sky, becoming the Pleiades star cluster. Their story is told across vast distances, and the sites along their path remain sacred. They represent women's solidarity and escape from unwanted pursuit.

archetypes.name: Tiddalik
archetypes.description: The great frog who drank all the water in the land, causing terrible drought. The animals had to make him laugh to release the water, which they finally did through the eel Nabunum's silly dancing. When Tiddalik laughed, the waters rushed out creating floods and filling the waterways. The story teaches about excess, community problem-solving, and balance.

archetypes.name: Wandjina
archetypes.description: The powerful ancestral beings of the Kimberley region, depicted in distinctive rock art with large eyes, halos, and no mouths (because their power over rain and storms would be too great if they could speak). They brought the wet season, created the landscape, and continue to control the monsoon rains. Their images must be repainted to ensure the coming of the rains.

archetypes.name: Yowie
archetypes.description: The hairy wild man of the bush who appears in Aboriginal traditions across Australia, used to keep children from wandering into dangerous wilderness. Whether originally a spirit being or a cultural memory, Yowie represents the dangers of the wild places beyond the safety of camp and the importance of respecting boundaries.

archetypes.name: Akshobhya Buddha
archetypes.description: The Immovable Buddha, lord of the Eastern Pure Land. Represents mirror-like wisdom that transforms anger into clarity. Associated with the vajra and the element of water.

archetypes.name: Amitabha Buddha
archetypes.description: Buddha of Infinite Light, ruler of the Western Pure Land (Sukhavati). Embodies compassionate acceptance and the promise of rebirth in a realm conducive to enlightenment.

archetypes.name: Amoghasiddhi Buddha
archetypes.description: The Buddha of Unfailing Accomplishment, lord of the Northern Pure Land. Represents all-accomplishing wisdom that transforms jealousy into skillful action.

archetypes.name: Avalokiteshvara
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of Compassion, who hears the cries of all beings. Takes many forms to help those in need. Source of the Om Mani Padme Hum mantra.

archetypes.name: Green Tara
archetypes.description: The Swift Liberator, female bodhisattva born from Avalokiteshvara's tear. Grants protection from the eight fears. Known for rapid response to prayers.

archetypes.name: Hayagriva
archetypes.description: The Horse-Necked One, wrathful form with a horse head emerging from his crown. Powerful destroyer of obstacles and protector against negative forces.

archetypes.name: Ksitigarbha
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of the Earth Store, who vowed to help all beings in the hell realms. Guardian of children and travelers. Known for the vow to liberate all beings from hell.

archetypes.name: Mahakala
archetypes.description: The Great Black One, wrathful protector of dharma. Fierce manifestation of compassionate wisdom. Destroys obstacles and negative forces through terrifying appearance.

archetypes.name: Maitreya
archetypes.description: The Future Buddha, currently residing in Tushita heaven awaiting the time to descend and renew the dharma. Embodies loving-kindness and the promise of future enlightenment.

archetypes.name: Manjushri
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of Wisdom, wielding the flaming sword that cuts through ignorance. Represents transcendent wisdom (prajna) and the clarity of enlightened mind.

archetypes.name: Mara
archetypes.description: The Lord of Desire and Death, who tempted Buddha under the Bodhi tree. Personification of the hindrances to enlightenment: desire, death, defilements, and doubt.

archetypes.name: Marpa the Translator
archetypes.description: The Translator, who brought tantric teachings from India to Tibet. Teacher of Milarepa. Known for his fierce teaching methods and householder lifestyle.

archetypes.name: Milarepa
archetypes.description: Tibet's most beloved yogi-poet, who transformed from a sorcerer-murderer to an enlightened saint. Embodies the possibility of complete redemption through practice.

archetypes.name: Naropa
archetypes.description: The Indian mahasiddha who systematized the Six Yogas. Former abbot who abandoned academia for direct realization under Tilopa. Teacher of Marpa.

archetypes.name: Padmasambhava
archetypes.description: The Lotus-Born, legendary tantric master who brought Buddhism to Tibet. Known as Guru Rinpoche. Considered a second Buddha who manifests in eight forms.

archetypes.name: Palden Lhamo
archetypes.description: The Glorious Goddess, chief female protector of Tibet. Rides a mule across a sea of blood. Fierce dharma protector who made vows to guard the dharma.

archetypes.name: Ratnasambhava Buddha
archetypes.description: The Jewel-Born Buddha, lord of the Southern Pure Land. Represents the wisdom of equality that transforms pride into generosity. Associated with abundance and enrichment.

archetypes.name: Samantabhadra
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of Universal Worthy, associated with practice and meditation. Rides a white elephant. Represents the actualization of enlightened activity.

archetypes.name: Shakyamuni Buddha
archetypes.description: The historical Buddha, Siddhartha Gautama, who achieved enlightenment under the Bodhi tree. The awakened teacher who founded Buddhism and revealed the path to liberation.

archetypes.name: Vairocana Buddha
archetypes.description: The Cosmic Buddha, embodiment of the Dharmakaya (truth body). Represents the dharmadhatu wisdom - the all-pervading awareness that is the ground of all reality.

archetypes.name: Vaishravana
archetypes.description: The King of the North, Guardian of Wealth and one of the Four Heavenly Kings. Protector and bestower of fortune. Rides a snow lion.

archetypes.name: Vajrapani
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of Power, wielder of the vajra (thunderbolt/diamond). Protector of Buddha and dharma. Represents the power of all buddhas.

archetypes.name: Vajrasattva
archetypes.description: The Diamond Being, embodiment of primordial purity. Central to purification practices. Holds vajra and bell, representing skillful means and wisdom.

archetypes.name: Vajrayogini
archetypes.description: The Diamond Female Yogi, semi-wrathful dakini representing the transformation of desire into enlightenment. Key deity in highest yoga tantra practices.

archetypes.name: White Tara
archetypes.description: The Mother of All Buddhas, embodiment of longevity, healing, and serenity. Has seven eyes to see all suffering. Associated with long life practices.

archetypes.name: Yamantaka
archetypes.description: The Destroyer of Death, wrathful form of Manjushri. Buffalo-headed protector who conquered Yama (death). Represents wisdom that transcends mortality.

archetypes.name: Yeshe Tsogyal
archetypes.description: The Princess of Wisdom Lake, chief consort of Padmasambhava and mother of Tibetan Buddhism. Achieved enlightenment and preserved the terma teachings.

archetypes.name: Aengus Óg
archetypes.description: God of love, youth, and poetic inspiration. Son of the Dagda and the river goddess Boann, conceived and born in a single day through magic. Associated with birds (especially swans) and dreams. Represents eternal youth, romantic love, and the magic of poetry.

archetypes.name: Arawn
archetypes.description: Welsh god of the underworld (Annwfn) and the Wild Hunt. Rules the Otherworld which in Welsh tradition is more paradise than place of punishment. Exchanges places with Pwyll for a year. Associated with hunting, hounds, and the autumnal passage of souls.

archetypes.name: Balor
archetypes.description: Giant king of the Fomorians with a single enormous eye that, when opened, destroys everything in its gaze. Grandfather of Lugh, destined to be slain by him. Represents the destructive forces of chaos, blight, and drought—the monstrous other that must be overcome.

archetypes.name: Brigid
archetypes.description: Triple goddess of poetry, smithcraft, and healing—the three sacred fires. Daughter of the Dagda, later syncretized with Saint Brigid. Keeper of the perpetual flame at Kildare. Embodies inspiration, transformation through fire, and the healing arts.

archetypes.name: Cernunnos
archetypes.description: Gaulish god of wild animals, forests, fertility, and wealth. Depicted with antlers, seated cross-legged, holding a torc and serpent, surrounded by animals. Represents the untamed wild, the cycles of nature, and the masculine principle of abundance and virility.

archetypes.name: Cú Chulainn
archetypes.description: Greatest hero of Irish mythology, son of Lugh and mortal Deichtine. Named for killing Culann's hound and becoming the smith's guardian in its place. Subject to ríastrad (warp spasm)—a terrifying battle transformation. Bound by multiple geasa (taboos) that ultimately lead to his death.

archetypes.name: The Dagda
archetypes.description: Chief of the Tuatha Dé Danann, father-god of immense appetites and powers. Wields the club that kills and resurrects, owns the cauldron of plenty that never empties, and plays the harp that controls seasons and emotions. Paradoxically depicted as both mighty king and comic glutton.

archetypes.name: Danu
archetypes.description: Primordial mother goddess, ancestor of the Tuatha Dé Danann (Peoples of the Goddess Danu). Little direct mythology survives, but her name marks the divine tribe and major rivers (Danube, Don). Represents the primordial source, the flowing waters of origin.

archetypes.name: Lugh
archetypes.description: God of light, skill, and craftsmanship—master of every art. Half-Tuatha Dé Danann, half-Fomorian. Slew his grandfather Balor with the sling-stone. Represents the ideal of excellence in all things, the champion who wins through skill rather than brute force.

relationships.target: Samildánach (master of all arts) and king

archetypes.name: Manannán mac Lir
archetypes.description: God of the sea, master of magic and illusion, guardian of the Otherworld. Rides the waves on his horse Enbarr, wears a cloak of mist, owns a ship that sails itself. Ferries souls to the Otherworld island of Emain Ablach. Trickster-magician of the waters.

archetypes.name: The Morrígan
archetypes.description: Triple war goddess of fate, death, and sovereignty. Appears as crow/raven over battlefields choosing the slain. Shape-shifts between maiden, woman, and crone. Offers sovereignty and prophecy to kings. Both terrifying and protective—the dark feminine that governs fate and battle-death.

archetypes.name: Nuada Airgetlám
archetypes.description: First king of the Tuatha Dé Danann who lost his arm in battle against the Fir Bolg. Given a functional silver arm by the god-physician Dian Cécht. Lost kingship because of blemish (Celtic kings must be whole), later restored. Represents sovereignty, sacrifice, and restoration.

archetypes.name: Rhiannon
archetypes.description: Welsh goddess of horses, sovereignty, and the Otherworld. Appears to Pwyll riding a magical white horse that cannot be caught. Falsely accused of killing her son, she is punished by carrying visitors like a horse. Later vindicated. Associated with birds whose song brings sleep and waking.

archetypes.name: Chang'e
archetypes.description: The goddess of the moon, originally the wife of the archer Hou Yi who shot down nine of ten suns. When she swallowed his elixir of immortality (either greedily or to prevent a thief from taking it), she floated to the moon where she dwells eternally in the Cold Palace with only a jade rabbit for company. She embodies the tragedy of immortality gained through loss.

archetypes.name: Chiyou
archetypes.description: The fearsome war god with bronze head, iron forehead, and the body of a beast, who led the Nine Li tribes against the Yellow Emperor. A master of metal-working who invented weapons, he commanded fog and storms in battle. Though defeated, he was later worshipped as a war god, representing the fierce, untamed aspects of martial power.

archetypes.name: Erlang Shen
archetypes.description: The three-eyed warrior god who can see through all deceptions with his third truth-seeing eye. Nephew of the Jade Emperor (his mother was a celestial who married a mortal), he is accompanied by his divine hound Xiaotianquan. He battled Sun Wukong to a standstill and is revered for controlling floods through engineering works.

archetypes.name: Fuxi
archetypes.description: The serpent-bodied culture hero who, with Nüwa, survived the great flood and repopulated the earth. He invented the bagua (eight trigrams), the basis of the I Ching and all Chinese cosmology. He taught humanity fishing, hunting, animal husbandry, and created the first writing system by observing patterns in nature.

archetypes.name: Guan Yu
archetypes.description: The deified general from the Three Kingdoms period, renowned for his loyalty to his sworn brother Liu Bei and his martial prowess with the Green Dragon Crescent Blade. After death, he was progressively deified, eventually becoming both a god of war and, paradoxically, a god of wealth and protection for merchants. His red face symbolizes loyalty and righteousness.

archetypes.name: Guanyin
archetypes.description: The Bodhisattva of Compassion who hears the cries of the world and responds to all who call upon her. Originally the male Avalokiteśvara in Indian Buddhism, she transformed in China into a feminine embodiment of infinite mercy. She appears in many forms to save beings from suffering, and vowed not to rest until all sentient beings are liberated.

archetypes.name: Hou Yi
archetypes.description: The divine archer who shot down nine of ten suns that were scorching the earth, saving humanity from destruction. For this act he was stripped of immortality by the Heavenly Emperor. He later obtained an elixir of immortality from Xiwangmu, but his wife Chang'e consumed it, leaving him to die mortal and alone, gazing at the moon where she dwells.

archetypes.name: Huangdi
archetypes.description: The Yellow Emperor, legendary founder of Chinese civilization and ancestor of all Han Chinese. He defeated the rebel Chiyou with the help of divine beings, unified the tribes, and invented (or his court invented) writing, the calendar, medicine, music, silk, and governmental systems. He ascended to heaven as an immortal on a dragon.

archetypes.name: Jade Emperor
archetypes.description: The supreme ruler of Heaven and all divine realms, presiding over the celestial bureaucracy that mirrors the Chinese imperial court. Originally a mortal prince who achieved immortality through countless lifetimes of cultivation, he governs through ministers, judges the living and dead, and maintains cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Lü Dongbin
archetypes.description: The most popular of the Eight Immortals, a Tang dynasty scholar who achieved immortality after passing ten trials from Zhongli Quan. He wields a demon-slaying sword and is the patron of scholars, barbers, and ink-makers. Known for his poetry and romantic adventures, he represents the integration of scholarly refinement with martial and magical power.

archetypes.name: Mazu
archetypes.description: The goddess of the sea and protector of sailors, fishermen, and travelers, originally a mortal woman named Lin Moniang from Fujian province who possessed supernatural powers from childhood. She saved her father and brothers at sea through spiritual projection and became the most widely worshipped deity in coastal China, Taiwan, and Southeast Asian Chinese communities.

archetypes.name: Nezha
archetypes.description: The eternally youthful warrior deity, born as a flesh ball after three years of pregnancy, who fought the Dragon King at age seven, killed himself to repay his debt to his parents, and was reborn from lotus roots. He wields fire-tipped spear, wind-fire wheels, and the cosmic ring Qiankun, serving as a fierce protector against demons.

archetypes.name: Nüwa
archetypes.description: The serpent-bodied goddess who created humanity from yellow earth, molding nobles individually and flicking mud from a rope for commoners. When the pillars of heaven collapsed, she melted five-colored stones to repair the sky, cut off a giant turtle's legs as new pillars, and burned reeds to stop floods. She established marriage and human civilization.

relationships.target: World-repairer who mends the broken sky

archetypes.name: Pangu
archetypes.description: The primordial giant who emerged from the cosmic egg and separated heaven (yang) and earth (yin). For 18,000 years he held them apart as they grew, then died and his body became the world - eyes as sun and moon, breath as wind, voice as thunder, blood as rivers, flesh as soil, hair as stars and vegetation.

archetypes.name: Shennong
archetypes.description: The Divine Farmer who taught humanity agriculture and medicine. With a transparent body that revealed the effects of plants, he personally tested hundreds of herbs - including seventy poisons in one day - to discover their medicinal properties. He invented the plow, established markets, and is considered the father of Chinese medicine.

archetypes.name: Sun Wukong
archetypes.description: The Monkey King, born from a stone egg, who mastered martial arts and magic, rebelled against Heaven, was imprisoned under a mountain for 500 years, then redeemed himself by protecting the monk Xuanzang on the journey to retrieve Buddhist scriptures. He embodies the transformation from chaos-rebel to enlightened protector.

archetypes.name: Xiwangmu
archetypes.description: The powerful Queen Mother of the West who dwells on Mount Kunlun, guardian of the peaches of immortality that ripen once every 3,000-9,000 years. Originally a fearsome goddess of plague and punishment with tiger teeth and leopard tail, she evolved into the serene queen of female immortals and supreme yin counterpart to the Jade Emperor.

archetypes.name: Yanluo Wang
archetypes.description: The king of the underworld and chief judge of the dead, derived from the Hindu/Buddhist Yama but adapted to Chinese bureaucratic cosmology. He presides over the courts of hell where souls are judged and assigned to appropriate punishments or rebirths. He keeps the Book of Life and Death recording every soul's fate.

archetypes.name: Zhongli Quan
archetypes.description: The leader of the Eight Immortals, a former Han dynasty general who achieved immortality through alchemical cultivation. He is depicted as a portly figure with bare belly, wielding a fan that can revive the dead. He represents the Taoist ideal of the achieved immortal who transcended death through spiritual cultivation.

archetypes.name: Anubis
archetypes.description: Jackal-headed god of mummification, the dead, and the underworld transition. Guide of souls to judgment, overseer of embalming, protector of graves. The liminal guardian between life and death.

archetypes.name: Apophis
archetypes.description: The giant serpent of chaos who attacks Ra's solar barque each night in the underworld. Embodies pure Isfet (chaos/evil) opposing Ma'at. Never defeated permanently—returns each night. The ultimate antagonist of cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Bastet
archetypes.description: Cat goddess of home, fertility, protection, and joy. Originally a fierce lioness protector, later depicted as gentle cat. Protector against evil spirits and disease. Associated with music, dance, and pleasure.

archetypes.name: Geb
archetypes.description: God of the earth, fertility, and the underworld caves. His body forms the earth, his laugh causes earthquakes. Father of Osiris, Isis, Set, and Nephthys. Separated from his consort Nut (sky) by Shu (air).

archetypes.name: Hathor
archetypes.description: Cow goddess of love, beauty, music, joy, fertility, and the afterlife. Mother and consort figure, welcomer of dead to the West. Can transform into wrathful Sekhmet. Embodies feminine creative and nurturing power.

archetypes.name: Horus
archetypes.description: Falcon-headed god of kingship, sky, and war. Son of Osiris and Isis, he avenged his father by battling Set for the throne. Every pharaoh was the living Horus. His eyes are the sun and moon.

relationships.target: Horus the Elder (Haroeris) — avenger and king

archetypes.name: Isis
archetypes.description: Goddess of magic, motherhood, healing, and wisdom. Reassembled and resurrected Osiris, conceived Horus, protected him from Set. Master of heka (magic), outwitted Ra to learn his secret name. The most powerful and beloved goddess.

archetypes.name: Ma'at
archetypes.description: Goddess personifying truth, justice, cosmic order, and balance. Her feather weighs against the heart of the deceased. More than a deity—she is the fundamental principle of cosmic harmony that gods and pharaohs must uphold.

archetypes.name: Nephthys
archetypes.description: Goddess of death, mourning, night, and protective magic. Sister and counterpart to Isis, mourner of Osiris. Associated with the liminal spaces, twilight, and the protective aspects of death. Often in Set's shadow but aligned with Osiris.

archetypes.name: Nut
archetypes.description: Goddess of the sky who swallows the sun each evening and gives birth to it each dawn. Her star-spangled body arches over the earth. Mother of Osiris, Isis, Set, Nephthys. Protective canopy over creation.

archetypes.name: Osiris
archetypes.description: God of death, resurrection, fertility, and the afterlife. Murdered by his brother Set, dismembered, and resurrected by Isis. Rules the underworld and judges the dead. The eternal dying-and-rising god.

archetypes.name: Ptah
archetypes.description: Creator god of Memphis who spoke the world into existence through divine thought and word. Patron of craftsmen, architects, and sculptors. Associated with the primordial mound and the creative power of language.

archetypes.name: Ra
archetypes.description: The supreme solar deity, creator god who sails across the sky by day and through the underworld by night, eternally battling Apophis. Source of all life, light, and cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Sekhmet
archetypes.description: Lion-headed goddess of war, plague, healing, and the fierce protective power of the sun. Ra's instrument of divine wrath. Nearly destroyed humanity in her bloodlust. Her rage must be appeased but also represents fierce protection.

archetypes.name: Set
archetypes.description: God of chaos, storms, desert, war, and foreigners. Murdered and dismembered his brother Osiris, battled Horus for 80 years. Complex deity: dangerous and disruptive but also protector of Ra against Apophis. Necessary chaos.

archetypes.name: Sobek
archetypes.description: Crocodile god of the Nile, fertility, military prowess, and pharaonic power. Embodies the dangerous but life-giving power of the river. Fierce protector and primal force. Associated with Seth but also Ra.

archetypes.name: Thoth
archetypes.description: God of writing, wisdom, magic, the moon, and time. Inventor of hieroglyphics, keeper of cosmic records, mediator between opposing forces. Weighs hearts in the Hall of Judgment. Master of secret knowledge.

archetypes.name: Akka
archetypes.description: The earth goddess and consort of Ukko, whose union with the sky god brings fertilizing rain. Associated with the rowan tree (whose Finnish name 'rauni' connects to her name Rauni), she represents the fertile earth receiving sky's blessing. She protects women, especially in childbirth, and governs the harvest.

archetypes.name: Ilmarinen
archetypes.description: The divine smith who forged the sky, the Sampo (source of endless prosperity), and many magical artifacts. His name connects to 'ilma' (air/weather), suggesting a sky-smith who hammered out the heavens. He represents the transformative power of craft, turning raw materials into magical creations. His tragic marriage to the Maiden of Pohjola ended in her death.

archetypes.name: Laima
archetypes.description: The Baltic goddess of fate who determines destiny at birth, particularly associated with women, childbirth, and the weaving of life's thread. She appears at births to pronounce the newborn's fate. Often appearing in triads, the Laimas weave, measure, and cut the thread of life. She protects women throughout their lives.

archetypes.name: Lemminkäinen
archetypes.description: The handsome, reckless warrior-lover of the Kalevala, known for his charm and impetuousness. His adventures include seducing the women of an island, being killed while trying to shoot the swan of Tuonela, and being resurrected by his mother who gathered his scattered pieces. He represents youthful passion without wisdom, energy without restraint.

archetypes.name: Louhi
archetypes.description: The powerful witch-queen of Pohjola (the North), main antagonist in the Kalevala. She commissioned the Sampo from Ilmarinen, offering her daughter as bride-price, then pursued the heroes when they stole it back. She can shapeshift, control weather, and wield powerful magic. She represents the hostile, dark powers of the frozen North.

archetypes.name: Mielikki
archetypes.description: The wife of Tapio and mistress of the forest, particularly associated with healing and the care of wounded animals. Her name may relate to 'honey' or 'pleasant,' reflecting her gentler nature. She heals forest creatures and must be propitiated for hunting success. She knows all forest medicines and can grant or withhold the forest's gifts.

archetypes.name: Perkūnas
archetypes.description: The Baltic thunder god, one of the most important deities in Lithuanian and Latvian tradition, closely related to Slavic Perun. He rides across the sky in a chariot, wielding an axe or hammer against evil spirits and the serpentine Velnias. He represents cosmic justice, punishing liars and oath-breakers with his lightning.

archetypes.name: Saulė
archetypes.description: The Baltic sun goddess who drives across the sky in a chariot, one of the most beloved deities. She is a nurturing, maternal figure who especially protects orphans and the unfortunate. Her mythic marriage to the Moon (Mėnulis) ended when he was unfaithful with the Morning Star, and Perkūnas cut him in pieces. She represents life-giving warmth.

archetypes.name: Tapio
archetypes.description: The Finnish god of forests, game animals, and the hunt. He appears as a tall figure covered in moss and bark, with a beard of lichen. Hunters must please him with offerings and songs to receive game. With his wife Mielikki and family, he rules the forest realm, protecting it while also granting its bounty to respectful hunters.

archetypes.name: Tuonetar
archetypes.description: The hostess of Tuonela who offers deadly hospitality to visitors - beer full of frogs, beds from which none rise. Wife of Tuoni and mother of diseases and death. She represents death as seductive rest, the dangerous comfort of giving up the struggle of life.

archetypes.name: Tuoni
archetypes.description: The lord of Tuonela, the Finnish realm of the dead, located beneath the earth and waters, reached by crossing a black river. With his wife Tuonetar, he rules the shadowy realm where the dead exist in a diminished state. Heroes who journey there face great danger, as Tuonela tries to keep all who enter.

archetypes.name: Ukko
archetypes.description: The supreme sky god of Finnish tradition, lord of thunder, weather, and crops. His name means 'old man,' reflecting his role as divine grandfather. He wields a hammer, axe, or sword to create lightning, and his sexual union with his consort Akka brings fertilizing rain. He became increasingly prominent as Finnish society developed.

archetypes.name: Väinämöinen
archetypes.description: The primordial sage and central hero of the Kalevala, born old from the primordial waters where he floated for centuries. The greatest singer and magician, he created the kantele (Finnish harp), wielded magic through song, and led the quest for the Sampo. At the end, he departed in a copper boat, leaving the kantele to his people, promising to return when needed.

relationships.target: Eternal wanderer who departs Finland, leaving the kantele

archetypes.name: Velnias
archetypes.description: The Baltic chthonic deity, counterpart to Perkūnas, associated with the underworld, cattle, wealth, and sometimes music. Originally a god of the dead and protector of flocks, he became demonized under Christianity. He retains trickster qualities and is often outwitted in folklore despite his power.

archetypes.name: Aphrodite
archetypes.description: Goddess of love, beauty, pleasure, and procreation. Born from sea foam, she embodies desire itself - the force that draws all things together.

archetypes.name: Aphrodite Pandemos
archetypes.description: Common Aphrodite - goddess of physical, earthly love. Sexuality, bodily desire, love accessible to all. Not 'lower' but grounded and embodied.

archetypes.name: Aphrodite Urania
archetypes.description: Heavenly Aphrodite - the celestial, spiritual aspect of love. Love of soul for soul, beauty as divine truth, Platonic eros ascending toward the Good.

archetypes.name: Apollo
archetypes.description: God of light, reason, prophecy, music, poetry, and healing. The ideal of classical beauty, clarity, and measured harmony. Twin of Artemis.

archetypes.name: Ares
archetypes.description: God of war, violence, and bloodlust. Unlike Athena's strategic warfare, Ares embodies the raw chaos and brutality of battle. Feared and disliked even by the gods.

archetypes.name: Artemis
archetypes.description: Goddess of the hunt, wilderness, moon, and childbirth. Virgin huntress who embodies wild feminine independence and the boundary between civilization and nature.

archetypes.name: Athena
archetypes.description: Goddess of wisdom, strategic warfare, and crafts. Born from Zeus's head fully armored. Represents rational intelligence, civilization, and the integrated feminine that needs no masculine completion.

archetypes.name: Cronus
archetypes.description: Titan king who ruled before Zeus, castrated his father Ouranos, and devoured his children to prevent prophecy of his overthrow. Embodies time that consumes, the old order, and the father who fears succession.

archetypes.name: Demeter
archetypes.description: Goddess of the harvest, agriculture, and fertility. The grieving mother whose loss brings winter and whose reunion brings spring. Embodies the nourishing earth and the fierce love of mother for child.

archetypes.name: Dionysus
archetypes.description: God of wine, ecstasy, theatre, and ritual madness. The twice-born who dissolves boundaries between divine and mortal, civilized and wild, self and other.

archetypes.name: Hades
archetypes.description: King of the Underworld, lord of the dead and hidden wealth. The unseen one who receives all souls. Represents depth, interiority, and the riches beneath the surface.

archetypes.name: Hephaestus
archetypes.description: God of fire, forge, and craftsmanship. The wounded creator - cast from Olympus, lame, yet maker of the most beautiful works. Represents transformation of suffering into art.

archetypes.name: Hera
archetypes.description: Queen of the gods, goddess of marriage, women, and family. Embodies the dignified and wrathful aspects of committed partnership.

archetypes.name: Heracles
archetypes.description: Greatest of Greek heroes, son of Zeus and mortal Alcmene. Performed the Twelve Labors, descended to the underworld, and was eventually deified. The quintessential Hero archetype struggling toward transcendence.

archetypes.name: Hermes
archetypes.description: Messenger of the gods, guide of souls, god of boundaries, travelers, thieves, and commerce. The quintessential trickster and threshold-crosser of Greek myth.

archetypes.name: Hestia
archetypes.description: Goddess of the hearth, home, and sacred fire. The still center around which all revolves. First and last in every offering, yet rarely appears in myth because she IS the center.

archetypes.name: Odysseus
archetypes.description: King of Ithaca, hero of the Trojan War, famed for cunning (metis). His ten-year journey home is the archetypal nostos - the return that transforms. Represents practical wisdom over brute strength.

archetypes.name: Penelope
archetypes.description: Queen of Ithaca, wife of Odysseus. Waited twenty years, fending off suitors through wit - her weaving and unweaving is cunning equal to her husband's. Embodies faithful patience as active resistance.

archetypes.name: Persephone
archetypes.description: Queen of the Underworld and goddess of spring. The maiden who descends and returns, embodying the cycle of death and rebirth, innocence transformed through the underworld journey.

archetypes.name: Poseidon
archetypes.description: God of the sea, earthquakes, and horses. Represents the vast emotional unconscious, instinctual power, and the forces beneath civilization.

archetypes.name: Prometheus
archetypes.description: Titan who stole fire from the gods and gave it to humanity. The suffering benefactor, chained to a rock for eternity. Embodies defiance of divine authority in service of human progress.

archetypes.name: Zeus
archetypes.description: King of the Olympian gods, ruler of sky and thunder. Father of gods and men. Upholder of cosmic and social order, yet also transgressor through his desires.

archetypes.name: Agni
archetypes.description: The Vedic fire god and divine messenger between humans and gods. Every sacrificial offering passes through Agni. One of the most important Rigvedic deities, invoked in more hymns than any other god. Represents the transformative power of fire — digestion, cremation, sacrifice, and illumination.

archetypes.name: Brahma
archetypes.description: The Creator god of the Trimurti, born from the cosmic lotus emerging from Vishnu's navel. Created the universe, the Vedas, and all beings. Paradoxically, the least worshipped of the Trimurti—creation, once done, recedes from devotional focus.

archetypes.name: Durga
archetypes.description: Warrior goddess created from the combined powers of all gods to defeat the demon Mahishasura, whom no male could kill. Rides a lion/tiger, wields weapons of all gods. Embodies fierce protection, righteous wrath, and the victory of dharma over adharma.

archetypes.name: Ganesha
archetypes.description: Elephant-headed god of beginnings, wisdom, and obstacle removal. Son of Shiva and Parvati, head replaced with elephant after Shiva beheaded him unknowingly. Invoked at the start of all undertakings. Represents the paradox of the obstacle that is also the path—removing obstacles or placing them to redirect.

archetypes.name: Hanuman
archetypes.description: Monkey god, son of Vayu (wind), supreme devotee of Rama. Embodies bhakti (devotion), selfless service, and incredible strength wielded only for dharma. Leaped across the ocean to Lanka, carried a mountain to save Lakshmana. The ideal servant whose ego is dissolved in devotion.

archetypes.name: Indra
archetypes.description: Vedic king of the gods, lord of storms, thunder, and war. Slew the serpent Vritra to release the cosmic waters. In later Hinduism, diminished—frequently humiliated by demons, saved by Vishnu/Shiva. Represents the old sky-father sovereignty that gave way to the Trimurti.

archetypes.name: Kali
archetypes.description: The terrifying goddess of time, death, and liberation. Black-skinned, blood-drenched, dancing on Shiva, wearing a garland of skulls and skirt of severed arms. Emerged from Durga's forehead to drink demon blood. Destroys ego, grants liberation. Paradoxically, the most loving mother—love that destroys illusion.

archetypes.name: Krishna
archetypes.description: Eighth avatar of Vishnu, complete divine incarnation. Most beloved and complex deity: mischievous child, divine lover of the gopis, philosopher-king of the Bhagavad Gita, cosmic lord. Plays the flute that enchants all creation. Teaches dharma, devotion, and non-attachment while fully engaging with the world.

archetypes.name: Lakshmi
archetypes.description: Goddess of wealth, fortune, prosperity, beauty, and grace. Emerged from the churning of the cosmic ocean. Consort of Vishnu, accompanying him in all avatars. Represents both material and spiritual abundance, the fullness of life, auspiciousness itself.

archetypes.name: Parvati
archetypes.description: Goddess of fertility, love, devotion, and divine marriage. Daughter of Himavan (Himalayas), won Shiva through intense tapas (austerity). Represents the devoted feminine that draws the divine masculine back from renunciation into engagement with the world. The gentle counterpart to Shiva's fierce aspects.

relationships.target: Parvati (patient ascetic who wins Shiva through tapas)

archetypes.name: Rama
archetypes.description: Seventh avatar of Vishnu, hero of the Ramayana. Represents the ideal of dharma—perfect son, husband, brother, and king. Exiled for 14 years, rescued Sita from Ravana with Hanuman's help. The archetype of righteous duty, even when it conflicts with personal desire.

relationships.target: Maryada Purushottam (ideal man who embodies dharma)

archetypes.name: Saraswati
archetypes.description: Goddess of knowledge, music, arts, speech, and learning. Pure white, seated on lotus or swan, playing the vina. Represents the flowing nature of wisdom, creativity, and articulate expression. Originally a river goddess whose waters symbolize the flow of knowledge.

archetypes.name: Shakti
archetypes.description: The primordial cosmic energy, the divine feminine power that activates and animates all existence. Without Shakti, Shiva is shava (corpse). She is both the transcendent Goddess and the immanent power in all things. Manifests as all goddesses—Durga, Kali, Lakshmi, Saraswati, Parvati.

archetypes.name: Shiva
archetypes.description: The Transformer/Destroyer of the Trimurti, but destruction in service of renewal. Both supreme ascetic and passionate lover. Dances the Tandava that creates and destroys universes. Embodies all paradoxes: ascetic/householder, fierce/gentle, destroyer/creator, male/female (Ardhanarishvara).

archetypes.name: Soma
archetypes.description: The Vedic deity of the sacred ritual drink and the moon. Soma is simultaneously a plant, a drink, a god, and the moon — a unique four-fold identity. The entire ninth mandala of the Rigveda is dedicated to Soma. Represents ecstasy, immortality, and the liminal state between mortal and divine.

archetypes.name: Varuna
archetypes.description: The Vedic sovereign god of cosmic order (rta), waters, and the night sky. In the earliest Rigvedic hymns, Varuna is the supreme cosmic ruler who upholds rta (cosmic truth/order) — a moral, ethical deity who watches all deeds with a thousand eyes. Later diminished to lord of oceans. Cognate with Greek Ouranos and Zoroastrian Ahura Mazda.

archetypes.name: Vishnu
archetypes.description: The Preserver of the Trimurti who maintains cosmic order (dharma). Descends as avatars whenever dharma declines. Blue-skinned, four-armed, reclining on the cosmic serpent Shesha. Represents the sustaining, protecting, balance-maintaining force of the cosmos.

archetypes.name: Yama
archetypes.description: God of death and the underworld, lord of dharma (justice). The first mortal to die, he became king of the dead. Judges souls based on karma. Rides a black buffalo, wields a noose and mace. Represents the inescapable law of death and moral consequence.

archetypes.name: Amaterasu-Ōmikami
archetypes.description: The supreme sun goddess and ruler of Takamagahara (the High Plain of Heaven), born from Izanagi's left eye during his purification. She is the divine ancestress of the Imperial line and the most revered deity in Shinto. Her withdrawal into the Heavenly Rock Cave and subsequent emergence symbolizes solar eclipse and restoration.

relationships.target: Imperial ancestress restored to cosmic sovereignty

archetypes.name: Benzaiten
archetypes.description: The goddess of music, arts, eloquence, and flowing things (water, words, music), derived from the Hindu Saraswati through Buddhist transmission. One of the Seven Lucky Gods (Shichifukujin), she is associated with serpents and dragons, islands, and bodies of water. She embodies the flow of creative and intellectual energy.

archetypes.name: Enma-Ō
archetypes.description: The king of the underworld and judge of the dead, derived from the Hindu/Buddhist Yama. He presides over the judgment of souls, consulting the Register of Sins and the Mirror of Karma. Despite his fearsome reputation, he serves cosmic justice rather than evil.

archetypes.name: Fūjin
archetypes.description: The wind god depicted carrying a large bag of winds, often paired with Raijin. He represents the vital breath that animates all life and the unpredictable, liberating power of wind. His iconography shows a wild, demonic figure releasing winds from his bag.

archetypes.name: Hachiman
archetypes.description: The syncretic kami of war and divine protection, identified with the legendary Emperor Ōjin and later adopted as a bodhisattva. He became the tutelary deity of the Minamoto clan and patron of samurai warriors. Unlike pure war gods, Hachiman emphasizes protection and righteous warfare rather than bloodlust.

archetypes.name: Inari-Ōkami
archetypes.description: The kami of rice, foxes, fertility, and prosperity - one of the most widely worshipped deities in Japan. Inari's gender is ambiguous or shifts, appearing as male, female, or androgynous. The white fox (kitsune) serves as Inari's messenger. Inari's domain expanded from agriculture to include industry, commerce, and worldly success.

archetypes.name: Izanagi-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The primordial male creator deity who, with his consort Izanami, stirred the cosmic ocean with the heavenly jeweled spear to create the islands of Japan. After Izanami's death, he descended to Yomi to retrieve her but fled in horror at her decayed form, then purified himself, giving birth to the three noble children.

archetypes.name: Izanami-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The primordial female creator deity and consort of Izanagi. After giving birth to the fire god Kagutsuchi, she died and descended to Yomi (the underworld), where she became the queen of the dead. Her transformation from life-giver to death-queen embodies the inseparability of creation and destruction.

relationships.target: Queen of Yomi (land of the dead)

archetypes.name: Jizō Bosatsu
archetypes.description: The beloved bodhisattva who protects children (especially deceased children), travelers, and beings in the hell realms. Small stone Jizō statues are ubiquitous in Japan, dressed in red bibs and caps by grieving parents. He vowed not to achieve Buddhahood until all hell realms are empty.

archetypes.name: Konohanasakuya-hime
archetypes.description: The beautiful blossom princess who married Ninigi, embodying the ephemeral beauty of cherry blossoms. When Ninigi doubted her children's paternity, she proved her fidelity by giving birth in a burning hut. She is enshrined as the deity of Mount Fuji and protects against volcanic eruptions.

archetypes.name: Ninigi-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The grandson of Amaterasu who descended from heaven to rule the terrestrial realm, carrying the three sacred treasures (mirror, sword, jewel). His descent (tenson kōrin) established the divine mandate of the Imperial line. He married the blossom princess Konohanasakuya-hime but rejected her sister, explaining human mortality.

archetypes.name: Ōkuninushi-no-Kami
archetypes.description: The great earthly kami who ruled Izumo and built the terrestrial realm. Descended from Susanoo, he overcame his brothers' attempts to kill him, won Susanoo's daughter through trials, and civilized the earth with the dwarf god Sukunabikona. He peacefully ceded rule to the heavenly kami, becoming the ruler of the unseen realm.

archetypes.name: Raijin
archetypes.description: The fearsome thunder god depicted with a ring of drums and a demonic appearance. Often paired with Fūjin (wind god), he represents the terrifying power of storms. Despite his fearsome appearance, he is also a protector, and thunder was believed to fertilize rice fields.

archetypes.name: Sarutahiko-Ōkami
archetypes.description: The powerful earthly kami (kunitsukami) who stood at the boundary between heaven and earth when Ninigi descended. His towering form and blazing eyes initially blocked the way until Uzume confronted him. He became the guide for the heavenly grandchild and the patron of travelers and martial artists.

archetypes.name: Susanoo-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The tempestuous storm god born from Izanagi's nose, ruler of the sea and storms. Exiled from heaven for tormenting Amaterasu, he descended to Izumo where he slew the eight-headed serpent Yamata-no-Orochi and discovered the sword Kusanagi. He embodies the transformation from chaos-bringer to culture-hero.

archetypes.name: Tsukuyomi-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The moon god born from Izanagi's right eye, ruler of the night. After killing the food goddess Ukemochi in disgust at her manner of producing food, he was banished by Amaterasu to rule the night separately from her day, explaining why sun and moon never meet.

archetypes.name: Ame-no-Uzume-no-Mikoto
archetypes.description: The goddess of dawn, mirth, and revelry whose ecstatic dance before the Heavenly Rock Cave lured Amaterasu out and restored light to the world. She embodies sacred performance, shamanic ecstasy, and the power of joy to overcome darkness. She later confronted the earthly kami Sarutahiko during the heavenly descent.

archetypes.name: Chalchiuhtlicue
archetypes.description: The goddess of flowing water - rivers, lakes, streams, and springs. Wife or sister of Tlaloc, she presided over the Fourth Sun which she destroyed with a great flood. She protects newborns and presides over the ritual bathing of infants. Despite her destructive power, she primarily represents the nurturing aspects of water.

archetypes.name: Coatlicue
archetypes.description: The terrifying earth mother whose skirt is woven of serpents and whose necklace is made of human hearts, hands, and skulls. She is the mother of Huitzilopochtli, the moon goddess Coyolxauhqui, and the stars. Impregnated by a ball of feathers while sweeping, she represents the earth that both gives life and reclaims the dead.

archetypes.name: Coyolxauhqui
archetypes.description: The moon goddess, daughter of Coatlicue and leader of the Centzon Huitznahua (Four Hundred Southerners/stars). She led her star-brothers to kill their mother upon learning of her miraculous pregnancy, but was slain and dismembered by the newborn Huitzilopochtli. Her severed head became the moon, forever circling the victorious sun.

archetypes.name: Hero Twins
archetypes.description: The Maya Hero Twins from the Popol Vuh who avenged their father and uncle (killed by the Lords of Xibalba) by descending to the underworld, defeating death through cleverness and willing sacrifice, then ascending to become the sun and moon. Their story is the central Maya myth of death, rebirth, and cosmic renewal through the ballgame.

archetypes.name: Huitzilopochtli
archetypes.description: The tribal god of the Mexica (Aztec) people who guided them from Aztlan to found Tenochtitlan. Born fully armed to defend his mother Coatlicue from his murderous siblings, he represents the sun that must be fed with blood to continue its journey. He embodies the Aztec mission of cosmic warfare to sustain the Fifth Sun through sacrifice.

archetypes.name: Itzamná
archetypes.description: The supreme Maya creator god, lord of the heavens and the day. He invented writing and the calendar, patron of learning and healing. Often depicted as an aged, toothless figure with a large nose, he represents the highest divine wisdom. His consort is Ix Chel. He is the father of the Bacabs who hold up the sky.

archetypes.name: Ix Chel
archetypes.description: The complex Maya moon goddess with both young and old aspects. As young Ix Chel, she is goddess of love, fertility, and the moon. As old Chak Chel, she is a fearsome crone who sends floods and destruction. She taught weaving and medicine to humanity. Her dual nature reflects the moon's phases and women's life stages.

archetypes.name: Mictecacihuatl
archetypes.description: The queen of Mictlan and wife of Mictlantecuhtli, guardian of the bones of the dead. She presides over the ancient festivals of the dead that evolved into modern Día de los Muertos. She watches over those who have died and ensures their spirits are honored by the living.

archetypes.name: Mictlantecuhtli
archetypes.description: The skeletal lord of Mictlan, the lowest level of the underworld where most souls journey after death. With his wife Mictecacihuatl, he rules over the dead who did not die special deaths (battle, sacrifice, childbirth, drowning). Quetzalcoatl had to trick him to retrieve the bones needed to create humanity.

archetypes.name: Nanahuatzin
archetypes.description: The humble, disease-covered god who threw himself into the sacrificial fire at Teotihuacan to become the Fifth Sun when the proud Tecuciztecatl hesitated. His courage and humility transformed him from the lowliest god to the most important, demonstrating that true sacrifice comes from the humble, not the proud.

archetypes.name: Quetzalcoatl
archetypes.description: The Feathered Serpent, one of the most important Mesoamerican deities, representing the union of earth (serpent) and sky (quetzal feathers). God of wind, learning, arts, civilization, and the morning star. As priest-king Ce Acatl Topiltzin, he opposed human sacrifice before being tricked by Tezcatlipoca into disgrace and exile, promising to return.

archetypes.name: Tezcatlipoca
archetypes.description: The Smoking Mirror, lord of night, sorcery, and destiny, whose obsidian mirror reveals all secrets and fates. He is both the supreme deity who tests and tempts, and the trickster who brought down Quetzalcoatl through deception. Patron of warriors and rulers, he represents the inescapable nature of fate and the dark powers necessary for cosmic balance.

archetypes.name: Tlaloc
archetypes.description: The ancient rain god with goggle eyes and jaguar fangs, predating the Aztecs by millennia. He controls the waters of heaven, sending rain for crops but also floods and lightning. His paradise Tlalocan receives those who die by drowning, lightning, or water-related diseases. Children were sacrificed to him, their tears sympathetically bringing rain.

archetypes.name: Tlazolteotl
archetypes.description: The goddess who inspires illicit sexual desire and then forgives and cleanses the sin. Penitents could confess their sins to her priests once in a lifetime, and she would 'eat' their transgressions. She presides over sexuality, filth (both physical and moral), and the purification that follows. She assists in childbirth and is associated with cotton and weaving.

archetypes.name: Tonatiuh
archetypes.description: The sun god of the current cosmic era, the Fifth Sun, who was created when Nanahuatzin threw himself into the fire at Teotihuacan. He refused to move until the other gods sacrificed themselves, establishing the pattern of sacrifice that sustains the sun. He is shown with his tongue out, thirsting for blood.

archetypes.name: Xipe Totec
archetypes.description: The flayed god of spring and renewal who wears the skin of sacrificial victims. His priests wore the skins of the flayed for twenty days until they rotted off, symbolizing the earth shedding its old skin for new growth. He represents the painful transformation necessary for renewal, the seed dying to become the plant.

archetypes.name: Xochiquetzal
archetypes.description: The eternally young and beautiful goddess of flowers, love, beauty, and the arts. Patron of lovers, artists, weavers, and prostitutes. She was abducted from her husband by Tezcatlipoca (or from Tlaloc, accounts vary), representing how beauty can be stolen but never truly possessed. She embodies innocent pleasure and artistic creativity.

archetypes.name: Anu
archetypes.description: Supreme sky god, father of gods, ruler of heaven. Remote and transcendent, rarely intervenes directly but grants authority to other gods. His word is absolute decree. Represents the distant, abstract divine authority.

archetypes.name: Apsu
archetypes.description: The primordial freshwater abyss beneath the earth, personified as a deity. With Tiamat (salt water), Apsu represents the primordial couple whose mingling waters generated the first gods. Slain by Enki/Ea, whose temple was built upon Apsu's body — making the abzu the foundation of cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Dumuzi
archetypes.description: God of shepherds, vegetation, and the dying-and-rising cycle. Consort of Inanna through sacred marriage. When Inanna returns from underworld, she condemns him as her substitute—he spends half the year below. The shepherd-king who dies and returns with the seasons.

archetypes.name: Enki
archetypes.description: God of wisdom, magic, fresh waters, crafts, and creation. The clever trickster-sage who solves problems through wit rather than force. Created humanity, saved Utnapishtim from the Flood by clever circumvention of Enlil's decree. Keeper of the me (divine powers).

archetypes.name: Enkidu
archetypes.description: Created by the gods to be Gilgamesh's equal and civilizing companion. Born wild, raised by animals, civilized by the sacred prostitute Shamhat. Becomes Gilgamesh's beloved friend and dies young after offending the gods. The Wild that is tamed and lost.

archetypes.name: Enlil
archetypes.description: God of wind, air, earth, and storms. Executive power of the cosmos—while Anu decrees, Enlil enacts. Commands the Tablet of Destinies. Can be benevolent (rain, fertility) or destructive (flood, plague). The active divine will.

archetypes.name: Ereshkigal
archetypes.description: Goddess and absolute ruler of the underworld (Kur/Irkalla). Sister and shadow-twin of Inanna. Alone among the dead, mourning in labor, furious and absolute in her realm. Even gods who enter her domain cannot leave. The inescapable Dread Queen.

archetypes.name: Gilgamesh
archetypes.description: Legendary king of Uruk, protagonist of humanity's oldest epic. Two-thirds god, one-third human. Befriends Enkidu (wild man), slays Humbaba, rejects Ishtar, loses Enkidu to death, journeys to find immortality, fails, and returns with wisdom instead. The archetypal hero's journey.

archetypes.name: Inanna
archetypes.description: Goddess of love, war, fertility, and political power. The most complex and dynamic Mesopotamian deity. Descends to the underworld and returns. Acquires the me (divine powers) through cunning. Embodies paradox: life and death, love and war, morning and evening star.

archetypes.name: Marduk
archetypes.description: Chief god of Babylon, hero of the Enuma Elish. Young champion who defeats Tiamat (primordial chaos) and creates the world from her body. Absorbs powers of all other gods, becomes supreme. The heroic cosmocrator who orders chaos.

archetypes.name: Nergal
archetypes.description: God of plague, war, death, and the underworld (co-ruler with Ereshkigal). Originally solar (setting/destructive sun), became underworld deity. Fierce, hot-tempered, dangerous. His descent to underworld and forced marriage to Ereshkigal is a violent love story.

archetypes.name: Shamash
archetypes.description: God of the sun and justice. Travels across sky by day, through underworld by night—sees all, judges all. Patron of law, truth, and oracles. Gives the law code to Hammurabi. The all-seeing eye of cosmic justice.

archetypes.name: Sin
archetypes.description: God of the moon, wisdom, and time-keeping. The moon counts months, regulates calendars, illuminates night. Father of Shamash and Inanna/Ishtar. Associated with cattle (crescent = horns). The quiet wisdom that rules the night.

archetypes.name: Tiamat
archetypes.description: Primordial goddess of salt water and chaos. With Apsu (fresh water), parents the first gods. Later becomes monstrous chaos-dragon when younger gods threaten her peace. Slain by Marduk, her body becomes heaven and earth. The original Mother who becomes Monster.

archetypes.name: Changing Woman
archetypes.description: The beloved Navajo deity who embodies the earth and its cycles, aging from young woman to old woman and back with the seasons. She created the four original Navajo clans from her own skin and established the Blessing Way ceremony. Mother of the Hero Twins by the Sun, she represents beauty, harmony, and the sacred cyclical nature of life.

archetypes.name: Coyote
archetypes.description: The great trickster of Western and Southwestern traditions, both creator and fool, who shaped the world through mistakes as much as intention. He stole fire for humanity, released death into the world, scattered the stars imperfectly across the sky, and continues to embody the paradox of sacred foolishness. He represents the unpredictable, transformative chaos necessary for life.

relationships.target: Culture-hero who brings fire and names the stars

archetypes.name: Glooscap
archetypes.description: The great culture hero and transformer of the Wabanaki confederacy (Abenaki, Mi'kmaq, Passamaquoddy, and others). He transformed the world to make it habitable for humans, shrinking giant animals, teaching skills, and defeating monsters. Unlike tricksters, he is generally benevolent and protective. He departed promising to return when his people need him.

archetypes.name: Hero Twins (Navajo)
archetypes.description: The twin sons of Changing Woman and the Sun who journeyed to their father, received weapons of lightning, and slew the monsters troubling the Navajo people. Monster Slayer is aggressive and direct; Born for Water is protective and thoughtful. Together they represent the balance of action and restraint needed to confront evil.

archetypes.name: Iktomi
archetypes.description: The Lakota trickster spider who was once a wisdom god but became the trickster through his own scheming. He invented language and stories but uses them to deceive. Creator of the dreamcatcher, he represents the trap of one's own cleverness. His tales teach through negative example, showing what happens when wisdom serves only ego.

archetypes.name: Kokopelli
archetypes.description: The humpbacked flute player depicted in ancient rock art throughout the Southwest, associated with fertility, agriculture, music, and trade. His hump carries seeds or trade goods; his flute brings warmth and fertility. He is a joyful, sometimes licentious figure who brings spring, enables conception, and represents the regenerative power of music and play.

archetypes.name: Raven
archetypes.description: The great trickster and creator of Pacific Northwest traditions who stole the sun from its keeper and released it into the sky, bringing light to the world. A shapeshifter and culture hero, he created humans, established customs, and constantly transforms between human and bird forms. Both sacred and profane, he embodies creative intelligence through cunning.

archetypes.name: Sedna
archetypes.description: The Inuit sea goddess dwelling at the bottom of the ocean, controlling sea mammals that are essential for survival. When taboos are broken, her hair becomes tangled and she withholds game. Shamans must journey to her realm to comb her hair and discover which taboos have been violated. Her origin involves betrayal, transformation, and her severed fingers becoming seals and whales.

archetypes.name: Selu
archetypes.description: The Cherokee Corn Mother who produced corn and beans from her own body, rubbing the grain from her flesh. When her sons discovered her secret and killed her in horror, she instructed them to drag her body over the ground, and where her blood fell, corn would grow. She represents the sacrificial gift of sustenance through transformation.

archetypes.name: Spider Woman
archetypes.description: The wise grandmother/creator figure who taught weaving to the Navajo and guided the Hero Twins against the monsters. In Hopi tradition, she is a creator who sang the world into being. She represents the creative power of thought given form, the web of life connecting all things, and the protective wisdom of the feminine elder.

archetypes.name: Sun Father
archetypes.description: The Sun as father deity across multiple Southwestern traditions. Father of the Hero Twins by Changing Woman, he tests them severely before acknowledging paternity and giving them weapons. He represents the life-giving power of the sun, the demanding father who tests before accepting, and the illuminating force of truth and vision.

archetypes.name: Thunderbird
archetypes.description: The great bird whose wingbeats create thunder and whose eyes flash lightning, found across North American traditions. The Thunderbirds are powerful sky beings who bring storms and rain, wage eternal war against underwater serpents/panthers, and maintain cosmic balance between upper and lower worlds. They test and empower humans who can withstand their presence.

archetypes.name: Underwater Panther
archetypes.description: The powerful water being of Great Lakes and Plains traditions, depicted with feline features, horns, scales, and a serpentine tail. Living in deep waters, it guards copper and medicine power while threatening those who disrespect water. In eternal conflict with Thunderbirds, it represents the necessary chthonic power balancing celestial forces.

archetypes.name: White Buffalo Calf Woman
archetypes.description: The sacred woman who brought the chanunpa (sacred pipe) to the Lakota people, teaching them the seven sacred ceremonies that maintain relationship between humans, earth, and sky. Appearing as a beautiful woman in white buckskin, she transformed a disrespectful man to bones while honoring the respectful one. She departed as a white buffalo calf, promising to return.

archetypes.name: Baldur
archetypes.description: God of light, purity, and beauty. The shining one whose death signals the beginning of Ragnarök. His invulnerability failed at mistletoe; his death breaks the world. Will return after Ragnarök.

relationships.target: Returned ruler of the post-Ragnarök world

archetypes.name: Fenrir
archetypes.description: The great wolf, son of Loki, bound by the gods until Ragnarök. Will swallow Odin at the end. Embodies chaos that cannot be destroyed, only temporarily contained.

archetypes.name: Freyja
archetypes.description: Vanir goddess of love, beauty, fertility, war, and seiðr magic. She claims half the battle-slain for her hall Sessrúmnir. Embodies feminine sovereignty, erotic power, and magical knowledge independent of male authority.

archetypes.name: Freyr
archetypes.description: Vanir god of fertility, prosperity, peace, and sunshine. Lord of Alfheim. Gave up his magic sword for love of Gerðr - will die unarmed at Ragnarök. Embodies masculine fertility and sacrifice for love.

archetypes.name: Frigg
archetypes.description: Queen of Asgard, goddess of marriage, motherhood, and domestic wisdom. Knows all fates but speaks none. Her silent knowledge and grief (for Baldur) represent the weight of seeing what cannot be changed.

archetypes.name: Heimdall
archetypes.description: Guardian of Bifröst, the watchman of the gods. Born of nine mothers, he needs less sleep than a bird, can see a hundred leagues, and will blow Gjallarhorn to announce Ragnarök. The eternal sentinel.

archetypes.name: Hel
archetypes.description: Daughter of Loki, ruler of the realm of the dead (Helheim). Half living and half corpse. Receives those who die of sickness or old age. Neither good nor evil - simply the face of necessary death.

archetypes.name: Jörmungandr
archetypes.description: The Midgard Serpent, child of Loki, who encircles the world biting its own tail. When it releases its tail, Ragnarök begins. Destined for mutual destruction with Thor.

archetypes.name: Loki
