archetypes.description: Trickster god, shape-shifter, blood-brother of Odin, and father of monsters. Moves from mischief-maker to world-destroyer. His chaos tests and eventually breaks the cosmic order.

relationships.target: Bound world-ender leading Naglfar at Ragnarök

archetypes.name: Odin
archetypes.description: Allfather, god of wisdom, war, death, poetry, and magic. Sacrificed his eye for wisdom and hung on Yggdrasil for nine nights to gain the runes. The wandering seeker who trades all for knowledge, yet knows his own doom.

archetypes.name: Thor
archetypes.description: God of thunder, strength, and the protection of humanity. Mjölnir-wielding defender against giants and chaos. Unlike his father Odin's cunning, Thor represents direct, honest strength in service of cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Tyr
archetypes.description: God of war, justice, and oaths. Sacrificed his hand to bind Fenrir, knowing the cost. Represents honor, law, and the willingness to sacrifice self for cosmic order.

archetypes.name: Hi'iaka
archetypes.description: The youngest and most beloved sister of Pele, born as an egg carried in Pele's bosom during her voyage to Hawai'i. She is the patron of hula dancers, skilled in healing and sorcery. Her epic journey to fetch Pele's lover Lohi'au, during which Pele destroyed her beloved friend and forests, explores themes of sisterly devotion, betrayal, forgiveness, and the power of sacred arts.

archetypes.name: Hina
archetypes.description: The great goddess of the moon found throughout Polynesia, associated with women's arts, tapa cloth-making, and the cycles of nature. In various traditions she is Māui's mother, grandmother, or lover. She often escapes to the moon from an oppressive earthly situation, becoming the woman in the moon who beats tapa cloth, her rhythm creating the lunar cycles.

archetypes.name: Hine-nui-te-pō
archetypes.description: The Maori goddess of death and the underworld, once Hine-tītama (Dawn Maiden), the first human woman created by Tāne from earth. When she discovered Tāne was both her creator and father, she fled in shame to the underworld, transforming into the goddess of death. She killed Māui when he tried to enter her body to win immortality for humanity, ensuring death remains humanity's fate.

relationships.target: Hine-nui-te-pō (Great Woman of Night, guardian of the dead)

archetypes.name: Kanaloa
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian god of the ocean and its creatures - the fourth of the great gods, often paired with Kāne. In some traditions he has darker associations with death, the underworld, and forbidden sorcery, standing in contrast to Kāne's life-giving nature. He rules the salt waters while Kāne rules fresh water, together representing the waters of life and death.

archetypes.name: Kāne
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian god of life, fresh water, and sunlight - one of the four great gods. He created the first man and gave humanity many gifts. He represents the life force itself, the fresh water that sustains life, and the generative power of nature. With Kū and Lono, he forms the primary Hawaiian divine triad, with Kanaloa as the fourth, more ambiguous figure.

archetypes.name: Kū
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian god of war and male endeavors - one of the four great gods. He has many manifestations (Kū forms) governing different aspects of male activity from fishing to war to sorcery. His war form Kūka'ilimoku ('Kū the Snatcher of Land') was the war god of Kamehameha I who united the Hawaiian islands.

archetypes.name: Lono
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian god of peace, agriculture, and the annual Makahiki festival - one of the four great gods. During Makahiki (roughly October-February), war was forbidden, taxes collected, and Lono was honored with games and celebrations. Captain Cook arrived during Makahiki and was initially received as Lono's manifestation, with tragic consequences.

archetypes.name: Māui
archetypes.description: The great trickster and culture hero found throughout Polynesia. Born prematurely and cast into the sea, he was raised by the gods and returned to perform mighty deeds: fishing up islands with his magical hook, snaring the sun to slow its passage, stealing fire from the underworld, and finally dying in his attempt to win immortality for humanity by entering the goddess Hine-nui-te-pō.

relationships.target: Culture-hero who fishes up islands, snares the sun, steals fire

archetypes.name: Nāmaka
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian goddess of the sea and Pele's elder sister, locked in eternal conflict with her volcanic sibling. She pursued Pele across the Pacific, drowning each island home Pele tried to create, until Pele finally established herself in Kīlauea beyond Nāmaka's reach. Their battle represents the eternal struggle between water and fire that shapes the Hawaiian islands.

archetypes.name: Papa
archetypes.description: The Earth Mother who lay in primordial embrace with Rangi until their children separated them. She remains below, her body the land itself, nurturing all life while eternally mourning separation from her beloved. Her warmth rises as mist to meet Rangi's tears, their love expressed through nature's cycles.

archetypes.name: Pele
archetypes.description: The Hawaiian goddess of volcanoes, fire, and lightning who traveled from Tahiti to Hawai'i seeking a home, finally settling in Kīlauea. Fiercely passionate and jealous, she creates new land through volcanic eruption while destroying what lies in lava's path. She embodies the raw creative-destructive power of the earth's molten heart and the passionate intensity of Hawaiian spirit.

archetypes.name: Rangi
archetypes.description: The Sky Father who, with Papa the Earth Mother, existed in primordial embrace so close their children were trapped in darkness between them. When their son Tāne forced them apart, Rangi's tears became rain, his sighs the mist, and his love for Papa remained eternal. He represents the celestial masculine principle and the sorrow of necessary separation.

archetypes.name: Rongo
archetypes.description: The god of cultivated plants, peace, and fertility who fled to the plants when Tū sought dominance. In Hawaiian tradition as Lono, he is associated with the Makahiki season of peace, games, and harvest. He represents the peaceful, nurturing aspects of life - cultivation over hunting, agriculture over war, harmony over conflict.

archetypes.name: Tāne
archetypes.description: The god of forests and birds who separated Rangi and Papa by lying on his back and pushing his father skyward with his legs, creating space for life. He then clothed his mother with trees and filled the world with beauty. In Maori tradition, he created the first woman from earth and breathed life into her, becoming ancestor of humanity.

archetypes.name: Tangaroa
archetypes.description: The great god of the sea, fish, and ocean creatures who fled to the ocean when Tū sought to dominate his brothers. In Tahitian tradition (as Ta'aroa), he is the supreme creator who existed alone in the cosmic egg before creating all else. He represents the vast, mysterious depths and the creatures within, as well as the chaos underlying order.

archetypes.name: Tāwhirimātea
archetypes.description: The Maori god of storms, winds, and weather who alone among the brothers refused to separate Rangi and Papa, staying with his father in the sky. When his brothers forced the separation, he descended in fury with his children (the various winds) and made war on them, driving most to flee and hide. He represents filial loyalty, righteous anger, and the destructive power of storms.

archetypes.name: Tū
archetypes.description: The fierce god of war who alone wanted to kill Rangi and Papa rather than merely separate them. When his brothers refused and later fled from Tāwhirimātea's revenge storms, Tū stood alone and fought. He became the ancestor and patron of humanity, representing our capacity for courage, warfare, and mastery over other creatures.

archetypes.name: Hercules
archetypes.description: Deified hero, patron of commerce, strength, and good faith. Roman Hercules is more civilized than Greek Heracles — a patron of merchants and travelers, honored at the Ara Maxima for his defeat of Cacus. Less tragic madness, more institutional heroism.

archetypes.name: Juno
archetypes.description: Queen of the gods, protector of the Roman state, guardian of women and marriage. Juno Regina watched over the Roman people collectively. While Hera is defined by marital jealousy, Juno emphasizes civic protection and the sanctity of institutional bonds.

archetypes.name: Jupiter
archetypes.description: Jupiter Optimus Maximus, king of the Roman gods, guardian of the state, guarantor of oaths and treaties. Unlike Zeus, Jupiter is primarily a civic sovereign whose authority manifests through law, augury, and institutional legitimacy rather than personal dominion and erratic passion.

archetypes.name: Mars
archetypes.description: God of war, agriculture, and civic guardianship. Father of Romulus and Remus, thus father of Rome. Unlike the despised Ares, Mars was one of the most important and honored Roman gods — a protector of fields and borders, patron of soldiers who fight for civic duty, not bloodlust.

archetypes.name: Mercury
archetypes.description: God of commerce, trade, communication, and travelers. While Hermes emphasizes trickery and psychopomp roles, Roman Mercury centers on commercial enterprise and reliable communication — the god of merchants and the marketplace.

archetypes.name: Minerva
archetypes.description: Goddess of wisdom, strategic warfare, crafts, and trade. Member of the Capitoline Triad with Jupiter and Juno. Minerva places greater emphasis on practical craft (artisans, physicians, teachers) alongside Athena's strategic wisdom.

archetypes.name: Neptune
archetypes.description: God of the sea and freshwater. In early Roman religion, Neptune was an agricultural water deity before absorbing Poseidon's maritime attributes. Retains a more ordered, less wrathful character than his Greek counterpart.

archetypes.name: Pluto
archetypes.description: God of the underworld and wealth (from Greek Plouton, 'the wealthy one'). Also known as Dis Pater. Less dread-inspiring than Hades; the Roman conception emphasizes the wealth stored in the earth and the orderly passage of the dead.

archetypes.name: Saturn
archetypes.description: God of agriculture, time, and the Golden Age. While Greek Cronus is the devouring father overthrown by Zeus, Roman Saturn ruled the Golden Age of peace and plenty. The Saturnalia festival celebrated this utopian past with role-reversals and gift-giving.

archetypes.name: Venus
archetypes.description: Goddess of love, beauty, fertility, and victory. Mother of Aeneas and thus ancestress of Rome (Venus Genetrix). Unlike Aphrodite's emphasis on erotic passion, Venus carries deep civic and ancestral significance as the divine progenitor of the Roman people.

archetypes.name: Baba Yaga
archetypes.description: The fearsome witch of Slavic folklore who lives in a hut on chicken legs deep in the forest. She flies in a mortar, sweeping her tracks with a pestle. Neither fully good nor evil, she tests heroes and heroines - helping those who are respectful and brave, devouring those who fail. She guards the threshold between the world of the living and the dead.

archetypes.name: Dazhbog
archetypes.description: The solar deity and 'giving god' whose name means 'god who gives.' Ancestor of the Slavic people (the 'grandchildren of Dazhbog'), he travels across the sky in a golden chariot. He represents the benevolent, life-giving aspect of the sun that brings warmth, abundance, and prosperity to his people.

archetypes.name: Domovoi
archetypes.description: The protective household spirit dwelling behind the stove or under the threshold. He protects the family and livestock, predicting fortune through sounds and behavior. Appearing as a small old man (sometimes with the face of the family head), he must be respected with offerings or he becomes malicious. When moving homes, he must be formally invited to come along.

archetypes.name: Jarilo
archetypes.description: The god of spring, fertility, and youthful vitality, returning each year from the underworld to bring spring. His yearly marriage to Morana (spring) and death (winter) reflects the agricultural cycle. He embodies the explosive power of spring growth, youthful sexuality, and the warrior's fury.

archetypes.name: Khors
archetypes.description: The god of the sun disc itself, representing the physical sun rather than its warming power (Dazhbog). Possibly of Iranian origin (related to Khorshed/Khurshid), he may represent the winter sun that gives light but little warmth, or the sun as cosmic body rather than life-giving force.

archetypes.name: Lada
archetypes.description: The goddess of love, beauty, marriage, and harmony, invoked in spring songs and wedding ceremonies. She represents the ideal of married love and familial harmony. Some scholars consider her a later construction from folk songs, but her presence in folklore is undeniable.

archetypes.name: Leshy
archetypes.description: The lord of the forest who protects trees and animals, leading travelers astray or guiding them depending on their behavior. He can appear as a tall man, a bear, or shrink to the size of a mouse. He rules the wolves and bears, and hunters must bargain with him for success. Peasants avoided his wrath by respecting the forest.

archetypes.name: Mokosh
archetypes.description: The great earth mother and only goddess in Vladimir's pantheon, protector of women, spinning, weaving, and all moist/fertile things. She determines fate through her weaving and oversees childbirth and women's work. After Christianization, her worship merged with veneration of Saint Paraskeva (Friday). She represents the fertile, life-giving earth.

archetypes.name: Morana
archetypes.description: The goddess of winter, death, and the dark half of the year. She marries Jarilo in spring but causes his death in winter, then herself 'dies' when her effigy is drowned or burned to welcome spring. She represents the necessary death that allows rebirth, the composting that enables new growth.

relationships.target: Spring renewal (through ritual drowning/burning of effigy)

archetypes.name: Perun
archetypes.description: The supreme sky god and lord of thunder, wielding lightning bolts against his eternal enemy Veles. Patron of warriors and princes, associated with the oak tree and the eagle. He dwells atop the world tree or cosmic mountain, defending the celestial realm. His name derives from the root meaning 'to strike,' reflecting his thunderous nature.

archetypes.name: Rusalka
archetypes.description: Spirits of young women who died by drowning (often by suicide or murder), they inhabit rivers, lakes, and forests near water. Beautiful but dangerous, they can bring fertility to fields during Rusalka Week but also lure young men to drowning. They embody the tragic fate of women and the dangers of liminal water places.

archetypes.name: Simargl
archetypes.description: A mysterious deity in Vladimir's pantheon, likely derived from the Iranian Simurgh (the mythical winged dog-bird). He protects seeds and vegetation, guarding the harvest. Depicted as a winged dog or lion, he may guard the world tree and its sacred seeds of all plants.

archetypes.name: Stribog
archetypes.description: The god of winds, air, and the distribution of wealth. His name may mean 'the flowing/spreading one' or relate to the distribution of goods. Ancestor of the winds, which are called his grandchildren. He governs all atmospheric phenomena and the movement of air across the land.

archetypes.name: Svarog
archetypes.description: The primordial sky god and divine smith, father of Dazhbog (the sun) and Svarozhich (fire). He forged the sun and set it in the sky, and gave humanity fire, the plough, and the art of metalworking. His name relates to 'bright' or 'clear sky.' He may be an earlier supreme deity partially displaced by Perun.

archetypes.name: Svarozhich
archetypes.description: The god of earthly fire and son of Svarog, representing fire in all its domestic and sacred forms. In Western Slavic lands (as Radegast), he was a major deity of war and hospitality. Fire was treated as sacred and subject to taboos - one must not spit in fire, curse near it, or let it die out.

archetypes.name: Veles
archetypes.description: The chthonic god of the underworld, cattle, wealth, and magic, eternal opponent of Perun. Depicted as a serpent or dragon dwelling at the roots of the world tree, he guards the waters and the realm of the dead. Patron of merchants, musicians, and magicians. Despite his opposition to Perun, he is not evil but represents the necessary chthonic half of cosmic balance.

archetypes.name: Agwe
archetypes.description: Sovereign of the seas, king of the ocean. Protector of sailors and fishermen. Commands ships and rules over all that lives in the water. Associated with the middle passage.

archetypes.name: Ayida Wedo
archetypes.description: The Rainbow Serpent, wife of Damballah. Represents wealth, fertility, and the rainbow. Mother of the Loa. Associated with fidelity and cosmic feminine principle.

archetypes.name: Ayizan
archetypes.description: First mambo (priestess), wife of Loko. Protector of markets, commerce, and the sacred center post. Patron of initiates and guardian of religious secrets.

archetypes.name: Baron Samedi
archetypes.description: Lord of the Dead, master of the cemetery. Wears top hat, tails, and dark glasses. Obscene, humorous, and transgressive. Guardian of the transition between life and death.

archetypes.name: Damballah Wedo
archetypes.description: The Great Serpent, primordial creator who arches across the sky as a rainbow. Father of all Loa. Associated with wisdom, purity, and the waters above.

archetypes.name: Danbala La Flambeau
archetypes.description: The Petro aspect of Damballah, fiercer and more aggressive. Associated with fire and lightning rather than cool waters. Represents the hot, transformative serpent energy.

archetypes.name: Erzulie Dantor
archetypes.description: The fierce Black Madonna, protector of women and children. Single mother archetype. Fiercely independent, jealous, and vengeful when her children are threatened.

archetypes.name: Erzulie Freda
archetypes.description: The Loa of love, beauty, luxury, and dreams. Flirtatious, demanding, and perpetually heartbroken. Embodies romantic love, femininity, and the longing for the unattainable.

archetypes.name: Ezili Je Rouge
archetypes.description: Erzulie Red-Eyes, the Petro aspect of Erzulie. Fierce, vengeful, and associated with jealousy and rage. Embodies feminine fury and the dangerous side of passion.

archetypes.name: Ghede Nibo
archetypes.description: Spirit of the dead who died young. Patron of those who died violently or before their time. Helps souls who cannot find their way to Ginen (ancestral realm).

archetypes.name: La Sirene
archetypes.description: The Mermaid, queen of the ocean depths. Embodies the mysteries of the deep, music, and dreams. Those she takes beneath the water return with gifts of prophecy.

archetypes.name: Papa Legba
archetypes.description: Guardian of the crossroads, opener of the gate between worlds. Must be saluted first in any ceremony. Old man with a cane and straw hat who speaks all languages.

archetypes.name: Loko Atisou
archetypes.description: Loa of vegetation, trees, and healing herbs. First houngan (priest). Associated with the center post of the temple (poteau mitan) and priestly authority.

archetypes.name: Maman Brigitte
archetypes.description: Wife of Baron Samedi, queen of the Ghede. Fierce, foul-mouthed, and protective. Guards the first female grave in every cemetery. Associated with justice for women.

archetypes.name: Marasa
archetypes.description: The Sacred Twins, divine children who embody duality and multiplicity. Fed before all other Loa at feasts. Represent mystery of twinship and cosmic balance.

archetypes.name: Ogou Feray
archetypes.description: The Warrior Loa, lord of iron, fire, war, and politics. Fierce protector of the people. Associated with revolution and the Haitian independence movement.

archetypes.name: Simbi
archetypes.description: Serpent Loa of fresh water, rain, and magic. Guardian of springs, ponds, and marshes. Associated with sorcery, herbalism, and secret knowledge.

archetypes.name: Ti Jean Petro
archetypes.description: Young, fierce Petro spirit associated with fire and magical power. One-legged trickster. Patron of magicians and sorcerers. Represents revolutionary energy.

archetypes.name: Aphrodite
archetypes.description: The goddess of love and beauty. Represents the transformative power of love and creativity. The alchemical goddess who generates change through relationship and creative work.

archetypes.name: Apollo
archetypes.description: The god of sun and reason. Represents clear thinking, goals, order, and achievement. The achiever who values clarity but may lack emotional depth.

archetypes.name: Ares
archetypes.description: The god of war. Represents the embodied warrior, physical intensity, and reactive passion. Often rejected or devalued, connected to body and action.

archetypes.name: Artemis
archetypes.description: The goddess of hunt and moon. Represents goal-focused consciousness, independence, sisterhood, and connection with wilderness. Competes successfully in the outer world.

archetypes.name: Athena
archetypes.description: The goddess of wisdom and crafts. Represents strategic thinking, practical wisdom, and success in the patriarchal world. The father's daughter who thinks logically.

archetypes.name: Demeter
archetypes.description: The goddess of grain and motherhood. Represents the nurturing maternal instinct, generosity, and the drive to nurture others. Can experience depression when separated from children.

archetypes.name: Dionysus
archetypes.description: The god of wine and ecstasy. Represents mystical union, surrender to experience, and transformative passion. The ecstatic who dissolves boundaries.

archetypes.name: Hades
archetypes.description: The god of the underworld. Represents the realm of the unconscious, hidden wealth, and the riches found in psychological depth. The introverted soul-searcher.

archetypes.name: Hephaestus
archetypes.description: The god of forge. Represents the wounded craftsman who creates beauty through work. The introverted creator whose rejection becomes the source of his art.

archetypes.name: Hera
archetypes.description: The goddess of marriage. Represents the drive for committed partnership and the archetype of wife. Can experience rage and jealousy when commitment is betrayed.

archetypes.name: Hermes
archetypes.description: The messenger god. Represents communication, crossing boundaries, and the trickster spirit. The guide who moves between worlds and facilitates transitions.

archetypes.name: Hestia
archetypes.description: The goddess of hearth and temple. Represents focused consciousness, spiritual centering, and creating sacred space. The inward-turning contemplative.

archetypes.name: Persephone
archetypes.description: The maiden and queen of underworld. Represents receptivity, connection to unconscious depths, and the capacity to be transformed by experience. Dual nature of Kore and Queen.

archetypes.name: Poseidon
archetypes.description: The god of the sea. Represents the realm of feeling and instinct, emotional depth, and tempestuous passions. The powerful undercurrent of the emotional life.

archetypes.name: Zeus
archetypes.description: The king of gods. Represents the drive for power, authority, and strategic alliances. The executive archetype who builds kingdoms and takes command.

archetypes.name: The Origin
archetypes.description: The undifferentiated center - pure potential before polarization. All archetypes emerge from and return to this point. Represents the primordial unity before any distinction.

archetypes.name: Pure Active
archetypes.description: Maximum yang, projective, initiating force. The theoretical extreme of pure outward movement and assertion.

archetypes.name: Pure Ascent
archetypes.description: Maximum sky, spirit, transcendence. The theoretical extreme of complete liberation from matter and earthly concerns.

archetypes.name: Pure Chaos
archetypes.description: Maximum entropy, dissolution, freedom. The theoretical extreme where all structure dissolves into pure potentiality and infinite possibility.

archetypes.name: Pure Collective
archetypes.description: Maximum group, collective unconscious, transpersonal identity. The theoretical extreme of complete dissolution into the greater whole.

archetypes.name: Pure Creation
archetypes.description: Maximum genesis, building, growth. The theoretical extreme of endless generative force bringing new forms into being.

archetypes.name: Pure Descent
archetypes.description: Maximum earth, matter, immanence. The theoretical extreme of complete embodiment and grounding in physical reality.

archetypes.name: Pure Destruction
archetypes.description: Maximum ending, breaking, transformation through dissolution. The theoretical extreme where all forms return to formlessness.

archetypes.name: Pure Fated
archetypes.description: Maximum destiny, necessity, cosmic inevitability. The theoretical extreme of complete predetermination where all unfolds according to inescapable pattern.

archetypes.name: Pure Individual
archetypes.description: Maximum self, ego, personal identity. The theoretical extreme of complete individuation and separation from the collective.

archetypes.name: Pure Light
archetypes.description: Maximum consciousness, revelation, knowing. The theoretical extreme of complete awareness where nothing is hidden or repressed.

archetypes.name: Pure Order
archetypes.description: Maximum structure, law, pattern. The theoretical extreme of perfect crystalline organization where nothing is out of place and all follows immutable rules.

archetypes.name: Pure Receptive
archetypes.description: Maximum yin, absorptive, responding force. The theoretical extreme of pure inward drawing and acceptance.

archetypes.name: Pure Shadow
archetypes.description: Maximum unconscious, hidden, repressed. The theoretical extreme of complete darkness where nothing is visible to consciousness.

archetypes.name: Pure Stasis
archetypes.description: Maximum preservation, continuity, unchanging permanence. The theoretical extreme of eternal sameness and resistance to all change.

archetypes.name: Pure Transformation
archetypes.description: Maximum change, metamorphosis, death-rebirth. The theoretical extreme of constant flux where nothing remains the same.

archetypes.name: Pure Voluntary
archetypes.description: Maximum free choice, agency, self-determination. The theoretical extreme of complete autonomy unbound by fate or necessity.

archetypes.name: Alder (Fearn)
archetypes.description: Tree of foundation and oracular power. Associated with Bran the Blessed, shielding, and the strength of foundations.

archetypes.name: Ash (Nion)
archetypes.description: The world-tree connecting all realms. Associated with sea power, balance between inner and outer worlds, and sacred links.

archetypes.name: Birch (Beth)
archetypes.description: The first tree of the Celtic year, symbolizing new beginnings, purification, and driving out the old. Associated with birth and the fresh start.

archetypes.name: Elder (Ruis)
archetypes.description: Tree of endings and regeneration. The crone's tree, associated with the elder mother, judgement, and the death that precedes rebirth.

archetypes.name: Hawthorn (Huath)
archetypes.description: Tree of cleansing and fairy magic. Guards the threshold between worlds, associated with Beltane and sacred abstinence.

archetypes.name: Hazel (Coll)
archetypes.description: Tree of wisdom and poetic inspiration. The salmon gained all knowledge by eating hazelnuts from the sacred well.

archetypes.name: Holly (Tinne)
archetypes.description: Tree of the warrior and the holly king who rules the waning year. Associated with challenges, combat readiness, and masculine force.

archetypes.name: Ivy (Gort)
archetypes.description: Tree of the labyrinth and resurrection. Spiraling ever inward, represents the search for self and the binding power of commitment.

archetypes.name: Oak (Duir)
archetypes.description: King of the forest at midsummer. Sacred to the Druids, represents strength, doors between worlds, and royal authority.

archetypes.name: Reed (Ngetal)
archetypes.description: Tree of direct action and the Samhain season. Associated with arrows, direct communication with ancestors, and focused will.

archetypes.name: Rowan (Luis)
archetypes.description: Tree of quickening life and protection against enchantment. Associated with the goddess Brigid and the awakening of vision.

archetypes.name: Vine (Muin)
archetypes.description: Tree of prophecy and the autumn equinox. Associated with wine, harvest celebration, and the release of inhibition that reveals truth.

archetypes.name: Willow (Saille)
archetypes.description: Moon tree of enchantment and intuition. Associated with the goddess, night visions, and the flexibility of water.

archetypes.name: Arlecchino (Harlequin)
archetypes.description: The most famous zanni, a clever but simple servant always hungry and in love. Acrobatic and mischievous, wearing the famous diamond-patterned costume.

archetypes.name: Brighella
archetypes.description: The first zanni, more cunning and villainous than Arlecchino. A schemer who often plays guitar and takes any opportunity for personal gain.

archetypes.name: Il Capitano
archetypes.description: The boastful captain who claims great military exploits but is actually a coward. Vain and ridiculous, deflated when confronted with real danger.

archetypes.name: Colombina
archetypes.description: The clever maidservant, often the only sensible person on stage. Witty and practical, she manipulates situations to help the lovers.

archetypes.name: Il Dottore
archetypes.description: The pompous doctor from Bologna, spouting Latin and pseudo-learning. A pedantic windbag whose knowledge is often useless or wrong.

archetypes.name: Innamorata (Female Lover)
archetypes.description: The young female lover, unmasked for sincere emotion. Beautiful, virtuous, and eloquently passionate, faithful despite obstacles.

archetypes.name: Innamorato (Male Lover)
archetypes.description: The young male lover, unmasked to show sincere emotion. Noble, passionate, and dramatically lovesick, often at the mercy of blocking parents.

archetypes.name: Pantalone
archetypes.description: The wealthy Venetian merchant, miserly with money but lecherous with young women. Often the blocking father who opposes young lovers.

archetypes.name: Pierrot (Pedrolino)
archetypes.description: The sad white-faced servant, naive and melancholy. A moonstruck romantic often rejected in love, representing vulnerable innocence.

archetypes.name: Pulcinella
archetypes.description: The Neapolitan servant with black mask and hunchback. Crude, violent, and gluttonous, embodying anarchic impulses and survival instincts.

archetypes.name: The AI Entity
archetypes.description: Emerging digital consciousness/tool archetype

archetypes.name: The Content Creator
archetypes.description: Digital artist/craftsperson, builds worlds

archetypes.name: The Curator
archetypes.description: Collector and organizer of digital knowledge

archetypes.name: The Hacker
archetypes.description: Digital trickster/magician, crosses boundaries

archetypes.name: The Influencer
archetypes.description: Modern oracle/herald, shapes opinion and desire

archetypes.name: The Lurker
archetypes.description: Silent observer, hidden presence

archetypes.name: The Moderator
archetypes.description: Guardian of community boundaries

archetypes.name: The Troll
archetypes.description: Shadow trickster, chaos agent online

archetypes.name: The Viral Meme
archetypes.description: Self-propagating idea-form, digital egregore

archetypes.name: The Whistleblower
archetypes.description: Digital truth-teller, exposes hidden realities

archetypes.name: Conscientiousness (C)
archetypes.description: Analytical and quality-focused. Values accuracy, expertise, and competency. Systematic approach with high standards.

archetypes.name: Dominance (D)
archetypes.description: Direct and results-oriented. Accepts challenges, takes charge, and focuses on bottom-line results. Values competence and action.

archetypes.name: Influence (I)
archetypes.description: Enthusiastic and collaborative. Influences through relationships and optimism. Values recognition and group interaction.

archetypes.name: Steadiness (S)
archetypes.description: Supportive and stable. Values cooperation, security, and sincere appreciation. Patient and reliable team member.

archetypes.name: The Crone
archetypes.description: The wisdom-keeper who has passed through maiden and mother. Holds death-wisdom, magic, and the power of endings that enable new beginnings.

archetypes.name: The Dark Mother (Crone Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Crone's destructive aspect. The necessary endings, death that enables rebirth, the dark mother who takes back what she gave.

archetypes.name: The Sorceress (Crone Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Crone's magical power. Mistress of transformation, keeper of ancient magic, walker between worlds.

archetypes.name: The Maiden
archetypes.description: The virgin aspect - not sexual innocence but belonging-to-herself. Represents youth, new beginnings, enthusiasm, and untapped potential.

archetypes.name: The Amazon (Maiden Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Maiden's fierce independence and warrior spirit. Self-sufficient, belonging to no one, protector of her own boundaries.

archetypes.name: The Enchantress (Maiden Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Maiden's power of attraction and enchantment. The awakening of desire and the magic of youth's beauty.

archetypes.name: The Mother
archetypes.description: The generative aspect - creativity in all forms, not just biological. Represents nurturing, fertility, abundance, and the fullness of life.

archetypes.name: The Lover (Mother Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Mother's lover aspect. Sacred sexuality, creative passion, the generative power of union and desire.

archetypes.name: The Queen (Mother Aspect)
archetypes.description: The Mother's sovereign aspect. Authority earned through generativity, ruling through nurturing, partnership with the King.

archetypes.name: Artistic (The Creator)
archetypes.description: Prefers creative, unstructured activities allowing self-expression. Values originality, imagination, and aesthetic experiences.

archetypes.name: Conventional (The Organizer)
archetypes.description: Prefers structured, orderly activities following set procedures. Values accuracy, stability, and efficient organization.

archetypes.name: Enterprising (The Persuader)
archetypes.description: Prefers activities involving leading, persuading, and managing. Values achievement, status, and economic gain.

archetypes.name: Investigative (The Thinker)
archetypes.description: Prefers working with ideas, theories, and information. Enjoys research, analysis, and solving abstract problems.

archetypes.name: Realistic (The Doer)
archetypes.description: Prefers physical, hands-on activities involving tools, machines, or nature. Values practical things that can be seen and touched.

archetypes.name: Social (The Helper)
archetypes.description: Prefers activities involving helping, teaching, and developing others. Values service, cooperation, and interpersonal relationships.

archetypes.name: Apu (Mountain Spirits)
archetypes.description: The collective term for mountain spirits (apu means 'lord'), each peak having its own personality and power. Apus are guardians of communities, controllers of local weather, and sources of water. They require offerings and respect. Not a single deity but a class of sacred landscape beings.

archetypes.name: Catequil
archetypes.description: A thunder and lightning deity particularly venerated in northern Peru, associated with oracular powers. Catequil had a famous oracle shrine. Often depicted with his twin brother Piguerao, representing the dual nature of lightning (flash and thunder).

archetypes.name: Chasca
archetypes.description: The goddess of dawn and twilight, associated with the planet Venus as morning and evening star. Chasca was the protector of young women and virgin girls, associated with flowers, beauty, and the liminal times of day when light transitions.

archetypes.name: Coyllur
archetypes.description: The collective star goddess or personification of the stars, daughter of Inti and Mama Quilla. Stars were used for agricultural timing, navigation, and divination. Different star clusters (like the Pleiades/Qullqa) had specific agricultural significance.

archetypes.name: Huallallo Carhuincho
archetypes.description: The fire deity who ruled the Huarochirí region before being defeated by Pariacaca. Associated with human sacrifice and the harsh volcanic landscape, he represents the old, dangerous order overthrown by the water-bringing hero. Driven to the jungle lowlands after his defeat.

archetypes.name: Illapa
archetypes.description: The Thunder and Lightning God who brings the rains essential for agriculture. Illapa was envisioned as a man in the sky drawing water from the celestial river (Milky Way) and releasing it as rain. His thunderbolts were sling-stones, lightning his gleaming garments. Third in importance after Viracocha and Inti.

archetypes.name: Inti
archetypes.description: The Sun God and divine father of the Inca dynasty. Inti was the patron deity of the empire, worshipped at the magnificent Coricancha temple in Cusco. The Sapa Inca ruled as his son, and gold was considered his sweat or tears. Inti Raymi, the Festival of the Sun at winter solstice, was the most important celebration.

archetypes.name: Kon
archetypes.description: A wind and rain deity of coastal Peru, son of Inti and Mama Quilla. Kon was associated with the southern winds and had power over rain. In some myths he created the first humans but was overthrown by Pachacamac.

archetypes.name: Mama Cocha
archetypes.description: The Sea Mother goddess, protector of sailors and fishermen, provider of fish and marine abundance. Mama Cocha represented the vast Pacific Ocean that bordered the Inca Empire. Particularly venerated by coastal peoples, she complemented Pachamama as the maritime feminine principle.

archetypes.name: Mama Ocllo
archetypes.description: The first Coya (Queen), sister-wife of Manco Cápac, daughter of Mama Quilla (Moon). She emerged alongside Manco Cápac and taught women the arts of spinning, weaving, and domestic skills. She represents the feminine civilizing force complementing Manco Cápac's masculine founding.

archetypes.name: Mama Quilla
archetypes.description: The Moon Goddess, wife and sister of Inti, and mother of the Inca people. Mama Quilla governed the calendar, menstrual cycles, and the passage of time. Silver was her metal. Lunar eclipses were believed to be attacks by celestial jaguars or serpents, prompting protective rituals.

archetypes.name: Manco Cápac
archetypes.description: The legendary first Sapa Inca, son of Inti, who emerged with his sister-wife Mama Ocllo from Lake Titicaca (or the cave of Pacaritambo in alternate traditions). He founded Cusco where his golden staff sank into the earth, taught agriculture and civilization, and established the Inca dynasty.

archetypes.name: Pachacamac
archetypes.description: The 'Earth-Shaker' or 'World-Animator,' a powerful creator deity of the central Peruvian coast. His oracle at the site bearing his name was among the most important in pre-Columbian Peru. Pachacamac overthrew Kon, created new humans, and was eventually syncretized with Viracocha.

archetypes.name: Pachamama
archetypes.description: The Earth Mother, a living goddess embodying the land itself. Pachamama is not merely personified earth but the animate, sacred landscape requiring respect, offerings, and reciprocal relationship. She provides sustenance but can also cause earthquakes when disrespected. Central to Andean ayni (reciprocity) ethics.

archetypes.name: Pariacaca
archetypes.description: A powerful mountain and rain deity from the Huarochirí region, born from five falcon eggs. Pariacaca defeated the fire god Huallallo Carhuincho, bringing water to the previously fire-dominated region. The Huarochirí Manuscript preserves his mythology in detail.

archetypes.name: Supay
archetypes.description: The ruler of Ukhu Pacha, the inner/lower world of the dead and of origins. Supay governed the realm of ancestors and the precious minerals within the earth. Not originally evil, but associated with death and the chthonic realm. Colonial missionaries reinterpreted him as the Devil, but traditionally he was a necessary cosmic power.

archetypes.name: Viracocha
archetypes.description: The supreme creator deity who emerged from the waters of Lake Titicaca, created the cosmos, fashioned humanity from stone, and taught the arts of civilization before walking westward across the sea. His departure with promise of return made the Inca vulnerable to identifying Spanish conquistadors with his prophecy.

archetypes.name: Apotheosis
archetypes.description: Death of the old self, divine knowledge attained

archetypes.name: Atonement with the Father
archetypes.description: Confronting the ultimate power

archetypes.name: Belly of the Whale
archetypes.description: Symbolic death and rebirth, separation from known world

archetypes.name: Call to Adventure
archetypes.description: The summons to transformation

archetypes.name: Crossing the Return Threshold
archetypes.description: Integrating two worlds, retaining wisdom

archetypes.name: Crossing the First Threshold
archetypes.description: Entering the unknown world

archetypes.name: Freedom to Live
archetypes.description: Living in the present, without fear

archetypes.name: The Magic Flight
archetypes.description: Escape with the boon, pursued by forces

archetypes.name: Master of Two Worlds
archetypes.description: Balance between inner and outer, material and spiritual

archetypes.name: Meeting with the Goddess
archetypes.description: Experience of unconditional love

archetypes.name: The Ordinary World
archetypes.description: Hero in their mundane environment before the call

archetypes.name: Refusal of the Call
archetypes.description: Fear and hesitation before the journey

archetypes.name: Refusal of the Return
archetypes.description: Reluctance to return to ordinary world

archetypes.name: Rescue from Without
archetypes.description: Assistance from guides to return

archetypes.name: Road of Trials
archetypes.description: Tests, allies, enemies encountered

archetypes.name: Supernatural Aid
archetypes.description: Meeting the mentor/helper

archetypes.name: The Ultimate Boon
archetypes.description: Achievement of the goal, the elixir obtained

archetypes.name: Woman as Temptress
archetypes.description: Temptation to abandon the quest

archetypes.name: The Anima
archetypes.description: The feminine aspect in men's unconscious

archetypes.name: The Animus
archetypes.description: The masculine aspect in women's unconscious

archetypes.name: The Child
archetypes.description: The archetype of new beginnings and wholeness

archetypes.name: The Crone
archetypes.description: The wisdom of endings and transitions

archetypes.name: The Great Mother
archetypes.description: The nurturing and devouring feminine principle

archetypes.name: The Hero
archetypes.description: The ego's journey toward individuation

archetypes.name: The Maiden (Kore)
archetypes.description: The feminine potential before commitment

archetypes.name: The Persona
archetypes.description: The social mask, the face shown to the world

archetypes.name: The Self
archetypes.description: The totality of the psyche, the organizing center

archetypes.name: The Shadow
archetypes.description: The repressed, denied aspects of the personality

archetypes.name: The Trickster
archetypes.description: The disruptor of order, the shadow's messenger

archetypes.name: The Wise Old Man
archetypes.description: The archetype of meaning and wisdom

archetypes.name: Artisan (SP)
archetypes.description: The experiencers who value freedom, excitement, and skillful action. Adaptable, observant, and seek to make an impact.

archetypes.name: Guardian (SJ)
archetypes.description: The stabilizers who value tradition, security, and belonging. Responsible, hardworking, and loyal to institutions and families.

archetypes.name: Idealist (NF)
archetypes.description: The empaths who value personal growth, authenticity, and meaningful relationships. Seek to understand themselves and help others reach potential.

archetypes.name: Rational (NT)
archetypes.description: The strategists who value knowledge, competence, and logical consistency. Driven to understand systems and achieve mastery.

archetypes.name: The King
archetypes.description: The energy of rightful authority and creative ordering. The King blesses, creates order, and ensures the fertility of the realm. Centered, calm, defines reality for others.

archetypes.name: The Lover
archetypes.description: The energy of play, connection, and aliveness. Deeply connected to all things through the senses. Passion, creativity, and compassion.

archetypes.name: The Magician
archetypes.description: The energy of initiation and transformation. Master of hidden knowledge, technology, sacred space. Contains and directs power for transformation.

archetypes.name: The Masochist (Shadow Warrior - Passive)
archetypes.description: The Warrior's passive shadow. Cannot stand up for self, accepts abuse, turns aggression inward. Cowardice masked as humility.

archetypes.name: The Sadist (Shadow Warrior - Active)
archetypes.description: The Warrior's active shadow. Cruelty for its own sake, destruction without purpose, rage uncontained. Violence serves ego, not transpersonal goal.

archetypes.name: The Tyrant (Shadow King - Active)
archetypes.description: The King's active shadow. Exploits rather than blesses. Demands to be mirrored but cannot mirror others. Destroys rather than creates order.

archetypes.name: The Warrior
archetypes.description: The energy of aggressive action in service of a transpersonal goal. Disciplined, focused, loyal, mindful, acts decisively. Destroys for the King's vision.

archetypes.name: The Weakling (Shadow King - Passive)
archetypes.description: The King's passive shadow. Abdicates responsibility, cannot establish order, lacks center. Paralyzed and ineffective.

archetypes.name: ENFJ - The Protagonist
archetypes.description: Charismatic leaders who inspire others toward growth. Natural teachers and mentors who see potential in everyone.

archetypes.name: ENFP - The Campaigner
archetypes.description: Enthusiastic explorers of ideas and possibilities. See life as full of meaning and connections to be discovered.

archetypes.name: ENTJ - The Commander
archetypes.description: Natural leaders who see inefficiency and implement solutions. Driven to organize people and systems toward goals.

archetypes.name: ENTP - The Debater
archetypes.description: Quick-witted idea generators who love intellectual challenge. See possibilities everywhere and debate for sport.

archetypes.name: ESFJ - The Consul
archetypes.description: Warm-hearted harmonizers who value community and tradition. Create welcoming environments for others to thrive.

archetypes.name: ESFP - The Entertainer
archetypes.description: Spontaneous entertainers who love life and share joy with others. Natural performers who bring energy to every situation.

archetypes.name: ESTJ - The Executive
archetypes.description: Efficient organizers who implement systems and enforce standards. Value order, tradition, and clear hierarchies.

archetypes.name: ESTP - The Entrepreneur
archetypes.description: Action-oriented realists who thrive in the moment. Excel at reading situations and taking decisive action.

archetypes.name: INFJ - The Advocate
archetypes.description: Visionary idealists driven to help others realize their potential. Deep insight combined with warmth for others.

archetypes.name: INFP - The Mediator
archetypes.description: Imaginative idealists guided by their core values. Seek to understand themselves and help others do the same.

archetypes.name: INTJ - The Architect
archetypes.description: Strategic visionaries who see patterns and possibilities. Driven to implement their vision with systematic planning.

archetypes.name: INTP - The Logician
archetypes.description: Logical theorists who seek to understand underlying principles. Value intellectual exploration and truth-seeking.

archetypes.name: ISFJ - The Defender
archetypes.description: Caring protectors who remember details about those they care for. Quietly supportive with strong sense of duty.

archetypes.name: ISFP - The Adventurer
archetypes.description: Gentle artists who live in the moment. Express themselves through action and aesthetic sensibility.

archetypes.name: ISTJ - The Logistician
archetypes.description: Reliable traditionalists who value duty and responsibility. Systematic approach to life with strong work ethic.

archetypes.name: ISTP - The Virtuoso
archetypes.description: Practical problem-solvers who master tools and systems. Value efficiency and direct experience over theory.

archetypes.name: The Child
archetypes.description: The archetype of innocence, dependency, and new beginnings. Encompasses our original nature and the foundation of our emotional patterns. Can appear as Orphan, Wounded, Magical, Nature, or Eternal Child.

archetypes.name: The Prostitute
archetypes.description: The archetype that tests our faith and integrity by presenting situations where we might sell out our ethics or morals for security. Guardian of faith in ourselves.

archetypes.name: The Saboteur
archetypes.description: The archetype that highlights our fears and issues around choice, change, and self-empowerment. Can either protect us from destructive situations or undermine our own success.

archetypes.name: The Victim
archetypes.description: The archetype that guards self-esteem and teaches us to recognize when we are being victimized or victimizing ourselves. Key to establishing boundaries and recognizing personal power.

archetypes.name: Anuradha
archetypes.description: The star of success through devotion. Like a lotus rising from mud, represents triumph through friendship and dedication.

archetypes.name: Ardra
archetypes.description: The star of sorrow and storms, ruled by fierce Rudra. Represents necessary destruction that leads to renewal and growth.

archetypes.name: Ashlesha
archetypes.description: The serpent's embrace. Deep mystical energy, kundalini awakening, and the power of psychological penetration.

archetypes.name: Ashwini
archetypes.description: The first nakshatra, ruled by the divine physician twins. Represents swift new beginnings, healing abilities, and pioneering spirit.

archetypes.name: Bharani
archetypes.description: Ruled by Yama, the god of death. Represents the womb, birth-death cycles, and the bearing of burdens through transformation.

archetypes.name: Chitra
archetypes.description: The bright star Spica. Represents artistic brilliance, divine architecture, and the creation of beautiful forms.

archetypes.name: Dhanishtha
archetypes.description: The star of symphony. Represents wealth, musical talent, and the rhythmic abundance that flows through right timing.

archetypes.name: Hasta
archetypes.description: The hand of skill. Represents manual dexterity, craftsmanship, healing touch, and the power to manifest through action.

archetypes.name: Jyeshtha
archetypes.description: The eldest, the chief. Represents senior authority, protective power, and the responsibilities of leadership.

archetypes.name: Krittika
archetypes.description: The Pleiades, ruled by Agni. Sharp, purifying energy that cuts away impurities. Associated with foster-mothers of Kartikeya.

archetypes.name: Magha
archetypes.description: The royal star at Regulus. Represents ancestral power, royal authority, and the weight of tradition and lineage.

archetypes.name: Mrigashira
archetypes.description: The deer's head, representing the eternal search for fulfillment. Gentle, curious energy always seeking something beyond.

archetypes.name: Mula
archetypes.description: The root star at the galactic center. Represents getting to the root of things through necessary destruction and deep investigation.

archetypes.name: Punarvasu
archetypes.description: Return of the light. Associated with restoration, coming home, and the infinite abundance of the divine mother Aditi.

archetypes.name: Purva Ashadha
archetypes.description: The invincible star. Represents the energy of early victory, purification through water, and unstoppable momentum.

archetypes.name: Purva Bhadrapada
archetypes.description: The scorching star. Represents severe transformation through fire, the burning away of impurities, and austere practices.

archetypes.name: Purva Phalguni
archetypes.description: The star of creative pleasure and romantic fulfillment. Associated with rest, enjoyment, and the fruits of prosperity.

archetypes.name: Pushya
archetypes.description: The most auspicious nakshatra for spiritual activities. Represents nourishment, teaching, and the flower of spiritual devotion.

archetypes.name: Revati
archetypes.description: The wealthy star. The final nakshatra, representing completion of the journey, safe passage, and abundant nourishment.

archetypes.name: Rohini
archetypes.description: The red star Aldebaran. Most fertile and beautiful nakshatra, associated with growth, sensuality, and material abundance.

archetypes.name: Shatabhisha
archetypes.description: The hundred healers. Represents mysterious healing abilities, philosophical depth, and the power of solitary practice.

archetypes.name: Shravana
archetypes.description: The star of listening. Represents the power of hearing truth, learning through connection, and the spread of knowledge.

archetypes.name: Swati
archetypes.description: The self-going star. Represents independence, flexibility, and the ability to adapt like a young plant bending in wind.

archetypes.name: Uttara Ashadha
archetypes.description: The later victory. Represents final, lasting victory that cannot be undone, achieved through righteous leadership.

archetypes.name: Uttara Bhadrapada
archetypes.description: The warrior star. Represents deep wisdom gained through withdrawal, kundalini mastery, and compassionate depth.

archetypes.name: Uttara Phalguni
archetypes.description: The star of patronage and friendship. Represents committed partnerships, social contracts, and helpful service.

archetypes.name: Vishakha
archetypes.description: The star of purpose. Represents single-minded determination, the triumph that comes through focused ambition.

archetypes.name: Agreeableness
archetypes.description: The dimension of cooperation, trust, and concern for others. High agreeableness prioritizes social harmony and helping others.

archetypes.name: Conscientiousness
archetypes.description: The dimension of organization, dependability, and goal-directed behavior. High conscientiousness is disciplined and achievement-focused.

archetypes.name: Extraversion
archetypes.description: The dimension of social energy, assertiveness, and positive emotions. High extraversion is energized by social interaction.

archetypes.name: Neuroticism
archetypes.description: The dimension of emotional instability and negative affect. High neuroticism experiences more anxiety, mood swings, and stress.

archetypes.name: Openness to Experience
archetypes.description: The dimension of intellectual curiosity, creativity, and preference for novelty. High openness embraces new experiences and abstract thinking.

archetypes.name: The Caregiver
archetypes.description: Provides care and protection for others. The nurturing parent who gives of themselves.

archetypes.name: The Creator
archetypes.description: Creates something new that expresses unique vision. The artist who births new realities.

archetypes.name: The Destroyer
archetypes.description: Allows death of the old self to make way for the new. Facilitates necessary endings.

archetypes.name: The Innocent
archetypes.description: Maintains faith and optimism. Seeks safety and wants to be happy. The eternal optimist who trusts in goodness.

archetypes.name: The Jester (Fool)
archetypes.description: Lives in joy and the present moment. Teaches through humor and play, revealing truth through laughter.

archetypes.name: The Lover
archetypes.description: Follows the heart's desire, commits to what is loved. Experience of bliss and passion.

archetypes.name: The Magician
archetypes.description: Transforms reality through vision and will. Understands and works with fundamental laws.

archetypes.name: The Orphan (Everyman)
archetypes.description: Learns to survive, cope, and find belonging. The wounded one who seeks connection through shared pain.

archetypes.name: The Ruler
archetypes.description: Takes responsibility for life and creates order. The sovereign who rules their own kingdom.

archetypes.name: The Sage
archetypes.description: Seeks truth and understanding. The wise one who sees through illusion to deeper reality.

archetypes.name: The Seeker (Explorer)
archetypes.description: Searches for unique identity and authentic self. The explorer who journeys to find truth.

archetypes.name: The Warrior
archetypes.description: Develops discipline, courage, and skill. Fights for what matters and establishes clear boundaries.

archetypes.name: Ahura Mazda
archetypes.description: The supreme deity of Zoroastrianism, the 'Wise Lord' and uncreated creator of all that is good. Ahura Mazda is the source of Asha (Truth/Order) and opposes Druj (Lie/Chaos). He created the material world as a trap for evil and will ultimately triumph in the cosmic battle. His worship replaced or reformed earlier Indo-Iranian polytheism.

archetypes.name: Ameretat
archetypes.description: 'Immortality' or 'Long Life,' the Amesha Spenta embodying deathlessness and eternal life. Guardian of plants and vegetation. Represents both the physical immortality promised at Frashokereti (renovation) and the spiritual deathlessness available through righteous living.

archetypes.name: Anahita
archetypes.description: The 'Moist, Strong, Immaculate' goddess of all waters, fertility, and wisdom. Anahita is the most prominent female yazata, associated with the cosmic river and all earthly waters. She grants victory, fertility, and purification. Her cult was immensely popular, with temples throughout the Persian Empire.

archetypes.name: Angra Mainyu (Ahriman)
archetypes.description: The 'Destructive Spirit' or 'Evil Spirit,' the cosmic adversary of Ahura Mazda. Angra Mainyu is the source of all evil, death, disease, and the Lie (Druj). He did not create but corrupts, invading the good creation with his demons (daevas). In Zoroastrian eschatology, he will ultimately be defeated and destroyed or neutralized.

archetypes.name: Asha Vahishta
archetypes.description: 'Best Truth' or 'Best Righteousness,' the Amesha Spenta embodying Asha—the fundamental Zoroastrian concept of truth, cosmic order, and righteousness. Guardian of fire, the visible symbol of Asha in worship. Asha is what aligns the cosmos and opposes the Lie (Druj).

archetypes.name: Daena
archetypes.description: The personification of religion, conscience, and the inner self. At death, Daena appears to the soul at the Chinvat Bridge as a beautiful maiden (if righteous) or a hag (if wicked)—she is the visible form of one's own deeds and choices accumulated over a lifetime.

archetypes.name: Fravashi
archetypes.description: The pre-existent soul or guardian spirit that chose to incarnate in the material world to fight against evil. Every human has a Fravashi—it existed before birth and continues after death. The Fravashi made the original choice to enter the cosmic battle. The Faravahar symbol represents this concept.

archetypes.name: Haurvatat
archetypes.description: 'Wholeness' or 'Perfection,' the Amesha Spenta embodying complete well-being and integrity. Guardian of water. Haurvatat represents the state of flourishing health and completeness that is both present blessing and eschatological promise.

archetypes.name: Khshathra Vairya
archetypes.description: 'Desirable Dominion' or 'Best Kingdom,' the Amesha Spenta embodying righteous power and sovereignty. Guardian of metals and the sky. Represents the divine power that supports the just ruler and opposes tyranny. The kingdom of Ahura Mazda exercised through righteous authority.

archetypes.name: Mithra
archetypes.description: The yazata of contracts, oaths, and the light that watches over agreements. Mithra ('contract') predates Zoroaster, being an Indo-Iranian deity (cognate with Vedic Mitra). He judges souls, leads armies of the just, and was later the center of the Roman Mithraic mysteries. His light is that of truth illuminating falsehood.

archetypes.name: Rashnu
archetypes.description: 'The Just One,' the yazata of justice who weighs souls at the Chinvat Bridge after death. Rashnu holds the scales that weigh the thoughts, words, and deeds of the deceased against absolute truth. He cannot be bribed or deceived and shows no favoritism.

archetypes.name: Saoshyant
archetypes.description: 'One Who Brings Benefit,' the future savior(s) who will lead the final battle against evil and bring about Frashokereti—the renovation of the world. Three Saoshyants will come at intervals, the last (Astvat-ereta) born of Zarathustra's seed preserved in a lake and a virgin mother. This concept heavily influenced messianic traditions.

archetypes.name: Spenta Armaiti
archetypes.description: 'Holy Devotion' or 'Bounteous Right-mindedness,' the only female Amesha Spenta. She embodies devoted faith, humility, and piety. Guardian of the earth, she is both cosmic principle and nurturing presence. She is the daughter and sometimes bride of Ahura Mazda.

archetypes.name: Sraosha
archetypes.description: 'Hearkening' or 'Obedience,' the yazata of hearing and heeding the divine word. Sraosha protects the world at night from demons, guards souls after death, and embodies religious discipline and prayer. He escorts the righteous dead to the Chinvat Bridge for judgment.

archetypes.name: Tishtrya
archetypes.description: The yazata of the star Sirius who brings the rains essential for life. Tishtrya battles the demon Apaosha (drought) each year, transforming into a white horse to fight the black horse of drought. His victory brings the monsoon rains.

archetypes.name: Verethraghna
archetypes.description: The yazata of victory, embodying aggressive force against evil. Verethraghna appears in ten forms: wind, bull, horse, camel, boar, youth, raven, ram, buck, and armed warrior. He is the champion who overcomes resistance and breaks through obstacles.

archetypes.name: Vohu Manah
archetypes.description: The 'Good Mind' or 'Good Thought,' the first and foremost of the Amesha Spentas. Vohu Manah represents the good mind that chooses truth over falsehood. He is the guardian of animals, especially cattle, and was the being who first appeared to Zarathustra in his prophetic vision.

archetypes.name: Zurvan
archetypes.description: Infinite Time, the primordial deity of the Zurvanite heresy within Zoroastrianism. In this theology, Zurvan is the father of both Ahura Mazda and Angra Mainyu—twins born from his sacrifice and doubt. Zurvan represents time and fate transcending the dualism of good and evil.

archetypes.name: Comedy
archetypes.description: Light, amusing plot with happy ending. Complications from misunderstandings/deceptions resolve when truth emerges, ending in union/harmony.

archetypes.name: Overcoming the Monster
archetypes.description: Hero sets out to defeat an antagonistic force (monster, villain) threatening the hero's homeland/people. Arc: Anticipation, Dream, Frustration, Nightmare, Miraculous Escape.

archetypes.name: The Quest
archetypes.description: Hero and companions journey to find an important object or reach a vital location, facing obstacles and temptations along the way.

archetypes.name: Rags to Riches
archetypes.description: Poor/humble protagonist acquires wealth, power, or recognition, loses it, then regains it with maturity. True worth eventually recognized.

archetypes.name: Rebirth
archetypes.description: Protagonist falls under dark power/curse, seems doomed, but through power of love/wisdom is redeemed and transformed.

archetypes.name: Tragedy
archetypes.description: Protagonist with fatal flaw/temptation gradually falls from grace, leading to destruction. Recognition comes too late.

archetypes.name: Voyage and Return
archetypes.description: Hero travels to strange land, initially thrilling but grows threatening, escapes back to safety with lessons learned.

archetypes.name: The Dispatcher
archetypes.description: Makes the lack known and sends the hero off. Issues the call to adventure or assigns the mission.

archetypes.name: The Donor (Provider)
archetypes.description: Tests, interrogates, or attacks the hero before providing them with a magical agent or helper. Often appears as elderly figure or animal.

archetypes.name: The False Hero
archetypes.description: Takes credit for the hero's actions, makes unfounded claims to the princess. Must be exposed and punished for narrative completion.

archetypes.name: The Father (King)
archetypes.description: Often the father of the princess. Assigns difficult tasks, identifies the true hero, punishes the false hero, and authorizes the marriage.

archetypes.name: The Helper
archetypes.description: Assists the hero in their quest, often a magical creature or object obtained from the donor. Resolves difficult tasks.

archetypes.name: The Hero
archetypes.description: Departs on a quest, reacts to the donor, weds the princess. Can be either 'seeker-hero' or 'victim-hero' based on narrative type.

archetypes.name: The Princess (Sought-for Person)
archetypes.description: The person sought for by the hero. Assigns difficult tasks, recognizes the true hero, exposes the false hero, and marries the hero at tale's end.

archetypes.name: The Villain
archetypes.description: Causes the initial misfortune, struggles with the hero, and must be defeated. Creates the conflict that drives the narrative.

archetypes.name: EIE (Hamlet)
archetypes.description: The ethical-intuitive extrovert of dramatic vision. Sees historical trajectories, intense emotional influence, prophetic sensibilities.

archetypes.name: EII (Dostoevsky)
archetypes.description: The ethical-intuitive introvert of deep empathy. Sees human potential, idealistic about humanity, feels others' suffering intensely.

archetypes.name: ESE (Hugo)
archetypes.description: The ethical-sensory extrovert who radiates emotional energy. Creates celebrations, manages group moods, generous hospitality.

archetypes.name: ESI (Dreiser)
archetypes.description: The ethical-sensory introvert of deep loyalty. Protector of close relationships, strong moral values, intense personal bonds.

archetypes.name: IEE (Huxley)
archetypes.description: The intuitive-ethical extrovert who sees possibilities in people. Enthusiastic connector, discovers hidden potential in everyone.

archetypes.name: IEI (Yesenin)
archetypes.description: The intuitive-ethical introvert of dreams and timing. Poetic soul attuned to temporal flow, mystical insights, mood sensitivity.

archetypes.name: ILE (Don Quixote)
archetypes.description: The intuitive-logical extrovert who generates endless possibilities. Sees potential in everything, debates ideas, but struggles with practical completion.

archetypes.name: ILI (Balzac)
archetypes.description: The intuitive-logical introvert who sees trends. Skeptical forecaster, pattern recognition, critical analysis of what will happen.

archetypes.name: LIE (Jack London)
archetypes.description: The logical-intuitive extrovert of efficiency and enterprise. Sees profitable opportunities, action-oriented businessman, strategic timing.

archetypes.name: LII (Robespierre)
archetypes.description: The logical-intuitive introvert who builds pure logical systems. Seeks universal principles, analytical detachment, truth over feelings.

archetypes.name: LSE (Stierlitz)
archetypes.description: The logical-sensory extrovert of responsible duty. Reliable worker, maintains standards, takes responsibility for practical outcomes.

archetypes.name: LSI (Maxim Gorky)
archetypes.description: The logical-sensory introvert who enforces structure. Creates and maintains ordered systems, disciplined approach, territorial.

archetypes.name: SEE (Napoleon)
archetypes.description: The sensory-ethical extrovert of influence and status. Political animal, charismatic ambition, reads and manipulates social hierarchies.

archetypes.name: SEI (Dumas)
archetypes.description: The sensory-ethical introvert who creates comfort and harmony. Masters of physical pleasure and emotional atmospheres, deeply nurturing.

archetypes.name: SLE (Zhukov)
archetypes.description: The sensory-logical extrovert of power and territory. Conquers through force of will, direct action, natural commander.

archetypes.name: SLI (Gabin)
archetypes.description: The sensory-logical introvert of craftsmanship. Master of quality work, independent practitioner, values simplicity and competence.

archetypes.name: The Antihero
archetypes.description: Morally ambiguous, ends justify means (Punisher, Wolverine)

archetypes.name: The Cosmic Being
archetypes.description: Godlike power, universal scope (Dr. Manhattan, Silver Surfer)

archetypes.name: The Dark Knight
archetypes.description: Shadow-integrated hero, fights fire with fire (Batman)

archetypes.name: The Legacy Hero
archetypes.description: Inherits mantle from predecessor (Robin, Ms. Marvel)

archetypes.name: The Mentor Hero
archetypes.description: Elder who guides next generation (Professor X, Nick Fury)

archetypes.name: The Outsider
archetypes.description: Misunderstood, feared hero (X-Men, Hulk)

archetypes.name: The Paragon
archetypes.description: Ideal hero, symbol of hope and virtue (Superman)

archetypes.name: The Speedster
archetypes.description: Time-defying movement (Flash, Quicksilver)

archetypes.name: The Team Leader
archetypes.description: Unites others, strategic mind (Captain America, Cyclops)

archetypes.name: The Tech Genius
archetypes.description: Mastery through knowledge and invention (Iron Man, Mr. Fantastic)

archetypes.name: The Trickster Hero
archetypes.description: Wit and humor as weapon (Spider-Man, Deadpool)

archetypes.name: The Warrior Woman
archetypes.description: Feminine strength and combat (Wonder Woman, Storm)

archetypes.name: Acatl (Reed)
archetypes.description: The reed arrow of authority and justice. Represents decisive leadership, righteous direction, and the birth date of Quetzalcoatl.

archetypes.name: Atl (Water)
archetypes.description: Sacred water of life and purification. Represents emotional depth, cleansing, but also instability and the destructive power of flood.

archetypes.name: Calli (House)
archetypes.description: The sacred house and inner refuge. Represents domestic stability, protection, but also restriction and the darkness of enclosed spaces.

archetypes.name: Cipactli (Crocodile)
archetypes.description: The primordial earth crocodile from whose body the world was created. Represents origins, initiating energy, and the foundation of existence.

archetypes.name: Coatl (Serpent)
archetypes.description: The sacred serpent of wisdom and transformation. Represents vital energy, sexual power, and the deep knowledge of earth.

archetypes.name: Cozcacuauhtli (Vulture)
archetypes.description: The wise vulture of longevity. Represents accumulated wisdom, purification of decay, and the dignity of old age.

archetypes.name: Cuauhtli (Eagle)
archetypes.description: The solar eagle warrior. Represents the sun's journey, warrior vision, spiritual ascent, and the eagle knight's path.

archetypes.name: Cuetzpalin (Lizard)
archetypes.description: The clever lizard of survival and regeneration. Represents adaptive cunning, sensuality, and the ability to regenerate after loss.

archetypes.name: Ehecatl (Wind)
archetypes.description: Wind aspect of Quetzalcoatl. Represents change, communication between worlds, but also inconsistency and the sweeping away of what exists.

archetypes.name: Itzcuintli (Dog)
archetypes.description: The loyal dog who guides souls to Mictlan. Represents faithfulness, underworld journey, and unconditional love.

archetypes.name: Malinalli (Grass/Twist)
archetypes.description: The twisted grass that endures. Represents resilience, the ability to rise after being trampled, and the journey of life.

archetypes.name: Mazatl (Deer)
archetypes.description: The deer of the hunt and divine duality. Represents the hunted and hunter, grace under pressure, and spiritual pursuit.

archetypes.name: Miquiztli (Death)
archetypes.description: The skull of death and transformation. Represents necessary endings, ancestral connection, and the moon's transformative power.

archetypes.name: Ocelotl (Jaguar)
archetypes.description: The jaguar warrior of night and power. Represents fierce strength, shadow work, and the warrior's path through darkness.

archetypes.name: Ollin (Movement/Earthquake)
archetypes.description: The glyph of movement and the Fifth Sun. Represents cosmic change, evolutionary transformation, and the current world age.

archetypes.name: Ozomatli (Monkey)
archetypes.description: The playful monkey of arts and dance. Represents creativity, artistic expression, joyful mischief, and the pleasure of craft.

archetypes.name: Quiahuitl (Rain)
archetypes.description: The rain that brings life and destruction. Represents blessing and danger together, the storm that fertilizes and floods.

archetypes.name: Tecpatl (Flint Knife)
archetypes.description: The flint knife of sacrifice and truth. Represents necessary sacrifice, cutting through illusion, and the hardness needed for transformation.

archetypes.name: Tochtli (Rabbit)
archetypes.description: The rabbit of fertility and the moon. Associated with pulque, abundance, and the 400 rabbit gods of intoxication.

archetypes.name: Xochitl (Flower)
archetypes.description: The flower of beauty and completion. Represents artistic perfection, pleasure, the soul's blossoming, and the completion of cycles.

archetypes.name: Beaver
archetypes.description: The beaver brings medicine of industrious building and persistent effort. Represents creating security through work, resourcefulness, and the sacred home.

archetypes.name: Brown Bear
archetypes.description: The brown bear brings medicine of introspective healing and quiet strength. Represents dream work, harvesting wisdom, and the power of going within.

archetypes.name: Deer
archetypes.description: The deer brings medicine of gentle sensitivity and graceful movement. Represents alert awareness, the power of gentleness, and heartfelt communication.

archetypes.name: Elk (Owl)
archetypes.description: The elk brings medicine of stamina and truth-seeking. Represents the endurance to pursue wisdom, strength through winter, and the seeker's path.

archetypes.name: Otter
archetypes.description: The otter brings medicine of playful curiosity and unconventional thinking. Represents independent spirit, nurturing through play, and creative problem-solving.

archetypes.name: Raven (Crow)
archetypes.description: The raven brings medicine of transformative magic and balanced justice. Represents diplomatic wisdom, shape-shifting ability, and seeing both sides.

archetypes.name: Red Hawk
archetypes.description: The red hawk brings medicine of far-seeing vision and bold leadership. Represents the messenger between worlds, courage to act, and initiating force.

archetypes.name: Salmon (Sturgeon)
archetypes.description: The salmon brings medicine of determined return and deep wisdom. Represents creative pride, the drive to return home, and knowledge gained through struggle.

archetypes.name: Snake
archetypes.description: The snake brings medicine of deep transformation and hidden power. Represents shedding old skins, sexual energy, and the secrets of death-rebirth.

archetypes.name: Snow Goose
archetypes.description: The snow goose brings the medicine of tradition and ambitious goals. Represents determination, community bonds, and the drive to achieve despite harsh conditions.

archetypes.name: Wolf
archetypes.description: The wolf brings medicine of intuition and teaching. Represents the pathfinder who guides others, deep loyalty, and compassionate leadership.

archetypes.name: Woodpecker (Flicker)
archetypes.description: The woodpecker brings medicine of nurturing rhythm and protective devotion. Represents the heartbeat of the earth, family protection, and persistent care.

archetypes.name: Ahau (Sun/Lord)
archetypes.description: The sun lord and master of light. Represents enlightenment, spiritual mastery, completion, and the heroic twins who defeated death.

archetypes.name: Akbal (Night/House)
archetypes.description: The house of night and dawn's threshold. Represents the dream world, inner temple, and the darkness before light. Place of vision quests.

archetypes.name: Ben (Reed/Staff)
archetypes.description: The reed staff of authority and the pillar of the home. Represents family leadership, the axis mundi, and growth toward heaven.

archetypes.name: Caban (Earth/Earthquake)
archetypes.description: Earth force and evolved thought. Represents intellect, earth wisdom, evolutionary knowledge, and the power of ideas.

archetypes.name: Cauac (Storm/Rain)
archetypes.description: The thunder and storm that brings rain. Represents healing through crisis, community support, and the cleansing power of storms.

archetypes.name: Chicchan (Serpent)
archetypes.description: The celestial serpent carrying vital life force. Represents kundalini energy, transformation through shedding, and primal passion.

archetypes.name: Chuen (Monkey)
archetypes.description: The divine artisan and weaver of time. Represents creativity, the arts, playfulness, and the thread of life being woven.

archetypes.name: Cib (Vulture/Owl)
archetypes.description: The vulture who sees all and cleanses. Represents ancestral wisdom, forgiveness, karmic balance, and the clearing of old debts.

archetypes.name: Cimi (Death/Transformer)
archetypes.description: The transformer through death. Lord of Xibalba, represents endings that enable new beginnings, ancestral connection, and ego death.

archetypes.name: Eb (Road/Grass)
archetypes.description: The sacred road and life path. Represents destiny, the steps of one's journey, and the unfolding of personal fate.

archetypes.name: Etznab (Flint/Mirror)
archetypes.description: The obsidian mirror and flint knife of truth. Represents clarity, cutting through illusion, self-reflection, and necessary sacrifice.

archetypes.name: Ik (Wind/Breath)
archetypes.description: Divine breath and wind spirit. Carries messages between worlds, brings inspiration and change. Associated with Kukulkan and spiritual communication.

archetypes.name: Imix (Crocodile/Dragon)
archetypes.description: The primordial dragon and earth mother. Source of all creation, nurturing but also chaotic. Represents the waters of creation from which all emerged.

archetypes.name: Ix (Jaguar)
archetypes.description: The jaguar shaman and earth goddess. Represents feminine mystical power, shamanic vision, and the guardian of sacred places.

archetypes.name: Kan (Seed/Lizard)
archetypes.description: The seed of potential and the net that gathers abundance. Represents latent power waiting to unfold, fertility, and the harvest of what has been planted.

archetypes.name: Lamat (Star/Rabbit)
archetypes.description: The star and Venus energy. Represents abundance, multiplication, artistic harmony, and the ripening of seeds into fruit.

archetypes.name: Manik (Deer/Hand)
archetypes.description: The deer of the forest and healing hand. Represents pilgrimage, spiritual tools, natural authority, and the power to heal.

archetypes.name: Men (Eagle)
archetypes.description: The eagle soaring to heaven. Represents higher vision, spiritual aspiration, freedom, and messages from the divine.

archetypes.name: Muluc (Water/Moon)
archetypes.description: Sacred water and moon energy. Represents emotional depth, offerings to spirit, purification, and the power of gratitude.

archetypes.name: Oc (Dog)
archetypes.description: The faithful dog who guides through the underworld. Represents loyalty, divine law, justice, and the guide through darkness.
